mi.origin: The mi radical is a pictograph of a standing person with a prominent, protruding stomach. it was originally a depiction of a pregnant woman, representing the physical "body" and the "self" as a complete, living vessel.
mi.story: Listen to your body! This radical represents the physical vessel we inhabit and the core substance of our very being. When you see it, think of personal health, your unique physical form, and the "meat" or essential substance of a story or object. It brings a sense of grounding, physical presence, and the fundamental nature of the individual self to every character it joins.
mi.position: Often appears as a standalone kanji or on the left side of complex characters.
mi.transformsMeaning: Indicates the physical body, personal status or social standing, health and physical condition, or the act of "shooting" out from the body (with the hand).

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for a person's physical "body" or their respected social "status" and "self" within the larger community.
Body (Ë∫´) + hand/inch (ÂØ∏). Imagine a person's "body" and a steady "hand" working together in perfect harmony to release a powerful arrow‚Äîthe physical act of shooting.
Words (Ë®Ä) + shoot (Â∞Ñ/Ë∫´). It originally meant to "shoot" out sincere "words" to release a heavy burden of social obligation‚Äîby apologizing or saying thank you.

mimi.name: Mimi
mimi.origin: A detailed pictograph of a human ear, clearly showing the outer ridges of the ear (the left line) and the earlobe (the bottom).
mimi.story: Listen closely to the whispers of the world! This character traces the delicate shape of the human ear. It represents the sense of hearing and the deep act of listening‚Äînot just to sounds, but to the wisdom that the wind and others bring to us.
mimi.position: Standalone kanji or on the left side (mimihen)
mimi.transformsMeaning: Relates to sound, the act of hearing, obedience (listening to orders), or things that have ear-like handles or projections

exampleKanji.explanation: Gate (ÈñÄ) + ear = imagine putting your ear against a heavy wooden gate to hear the secrets being whispered on the other side.
Ear + hand (Âèà) = in ancient times, the 'ear' was taken as a trophy of capture. Now it means to take or obtain something with your hand.
Ear + mouth + king (Áéã simplified) = a person who truly 'listens' to the divine and speaks with the wisdom of a great king.

mimihen.name: Mimihen
mimihen.origin: A compressed form of the ËÄ≥ (ear) kanji. It remains a pictograph of a human ear with its distinctive outer rim and delicate inner folds, narrowed specifically to fit perfectly on the left side of more complex characters.
mimihen.story: Lend me your ears! This radical brings the power of hearing, the deep act of listening, and the perception of every sound in the environment to its kanji. When it sits on the left, think of listening carefully, specific sounds like shouts or whispers, and the profound "attention" we pay to the world and the people around us. It is the radical of the master listener and the one who pays close attention to the finest details.
mimihen.position: Always appears on the LEFT side of the kanji.
mimihen.transformsMeaning: Indicates the physical ear and hearing, listening carefully, paying attention, professional jobs (listening to records), or the concept of being "holy" (listening to divine wisdom).

exampleKanji.explanation: Ear (ËÄ≥) + sound/mark (Èü≥/Êà†). Originally related to a person who "listens" to and "marks" official records with extreme care‚Äîthe definition of a professional post.
Ear (ËÄ≥) + heart (ÂøÉ) + virtue (Âæ≥/°©ú). To "listen" with your whole "ear" and your sincere "heart" at the same time‚Äîthe act of paying true, deep attention.
Ear (ËÄ≥) + mouth (Âè£) + king (Áéã). Someone who can "listen" to the high wisdom of the universe and "speak" it with the authority of a "king"‚Äîthe definition of a holy person.

miru.name: Miru
miru.origin: The miru radical is a powerful pictograph of a massive eye (ÁõÆ) sitting on top of a person's legs (ÂÑø). It depicts a person standing tall and actively looking, watching, or examining the world around them from as high a vantage point as possible.
miru.story: I see you clearly! This radical represents the active, conscious act of looking at the world. While the "eye" radical alone is static, "miru" is dynamic‚Äîit‚Äôs a person using their legs to reach a viewpoint and their eyes to meticulously observe every detail. When you see it, think of watching, witnessing, and the deep understanding that comes from direct, firsthand observation. It is the radical of the observer, the examiner, and the witness to history.
miru.position: Often appears as a standalone kanji or at the bottom/right of complex characters.
miru.transformsMeaning: Indicates the act of seeing or watching, mental understanding (insight), being a parent (watching over ), setting standards (seeing what is right), or specific types of visual examination.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for the physical act of seeing or the mental act of perceiving a situation and gaining a clear understanding of it.
Stand (Á´ã) + tree (Êú®) + see (Ë¶ã). Traditionally, a "parent" is someone who "stands" high on a "tree" to "watch" over and protect their child from harm at all times.
Husband/man (Â§´) + see (Ë¶ã). A respected person who "sees" and clearly defines the "rules" and "standards" that must be followed to maintain order in a community.

mizu.name: Mizu
mizu.origin: A pictograph of a flowing stream. The central vertical stroke represents the main current, and the side strokes are the ripples and splashes of water as it moves.
mizu.story: See the river flowing before you! The strong central line is the deep, powerful current, while the smaller strokes on the sides are the splashes of water hitting rocks in the stream. Water is the essence of life, constantly changing and flowing through the world.
mizu.position: Standalone or usually at the bottom of the kanji
mizu.transformsMeaning: Relates to liquids, the act of flowing, wetness, or the concept of purification

exampleKanji.explanation: Water + a drop (the dot) = a drop of water that has been 'stopped' or frozen solid by the cold.
White (ÁôΩ) + water = the pure, 'white' water bubbling up from a clear spring deep in the earth.
Meat (Â§ï form) + hand (Âèà) + water (Á§∫ simplified) = the ritual of washing hands and offering food at a sacred festival.

mizugame.name: Mizugame
mizugame.origin: The mizugame radical is a pictograph of an earthenware jar featuring a sturdy, well-fitted lid. It represents various containers made of pottery or metal designed specifically to hold precious liquids or store essential household goods for long periods.
mizugame.story: Fill it to the brim! This radical represents the durable, simple containers that have kept our water fresh and our food secure for countless generations. When you see it, think of heavy clay jars, modern metal cans, and the vital, everyday act of storage and preservation. It brings a sense of containment, protective boundaries, and the functional beauty of household vessels to any character it joins.
mizugame.position: Often appears as a standalone kanji or on the left/right side of more complex characters.
mizugame.transformsMeaning: Indicates pottery and clay vessels, modern cans and tins, the act of storage or containment, or things that are cracked and broken (like a dropped jar).

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for a modern metal "can" or a traditional, heavy pottery "jar" used for the long-term storage of food or liquids.
Jar (Áº∂) + stork (Èõö). A large, industrial-sized or specialized pottery "jar" or "can" designed for the storage and transport of larger quantities of goods.
Jar (Áº∂) + shout/tiger marks (Ëôñ). Imagine a heavy pottery "jar" that has sustained a large, jagged "crack"‚Äîthe literal definition of a physical fissure or gap.

mizukara.name: Mizukara
mizukara.origin: The mizukara radical is a pictograph of a human nose. In ancient times, people in East Asia would point directly to their nose to refer to themselves, leading to the universal meaning of "self" or "oneself." It also came to represent the starting point or origin ("from") of an action.
mizukara.story: Point to yourself! This radical represents your unique identity and the very starting point of all your actions. When you see it, think of your own presence, your individual self, and the deep origin of a movement or a thought. It brings the power of personal identity and the concept of "starting from within" to every character it joins, reminding us that every journey begins with the individual.
mizukara.position: Often appears as a standalone kanji or at the top of complex characters.
mizukara.transformsMeaning: Indicates the self or oneself, the concept of "naturally" or "automatically" (from within), the starting point or origin of time/space, and the physical nose and smelling.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for referring to oneself, the point where a journey begins, or things that happen automatically (from their own nature).
Self/nose (Ëá™) + dog (Áä¨). Imagine a sensitive "dog" using its sharp "nose" (the self-referencing organ) to detect a powerful and distinctive scent.
Self/nose (Ëá™) + specialized air passages. The physical "nose" itself, the very organ that people point to when they say "me."

mochiiru.name: Mochiiru
mochiiru.origin: The mochiiru radical is a pictograph of a functional wooden bucket or a specifically designed tool. It depicts an object that has a clear, practical "use" or "utility" in the daily rhythm of human life and work.
mochiiru.story: Put it to good work! This radical represents the tools, methods, and procedures we use to solve problems and get things done efficiently. When you see it, think of high productivity, important business affairs, and the sheer practical utility of an object or an idea. It brings a sense of focused activity, functional purpose, and the industrious spirit of work to any character it joins.
mochiiru.position: Often appears as a standalone kanji or as a central component in complex characters.
mochiiru.transformsMeaning: Indicates using an object or method, business affairs and tasks, utility and function, or things that are "ordinary" (having the same general use).

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for using a physical tool or being actively involved in a specific professional task or "business" affair.
A person (‰∫∫) + grass/herb (Ëâπ) + to use (Áî®). To provide a "person" with all the essential "tools" and materials they can "use" to be fully and expertly prepared.
Building/slant roof (Âπø) + to use (Áî®). Originally referred to something that had a regular, "building-wide" utility‚Äîrepresenting the "common" or standard way of doing things.

mongamae.name: Mongamae
mongamae.origin: A detailed pictograph of a traditional large gate with two swinging doors. You can see the two door panels on either side and the frame that holds them together.
mongamae.story: Imagine the grand entrance to a temple or a fortress! Two heavy wooden doors stand ready to swing wide. This radical encloses other elements just like a doorway frames the world beyond it. It is the sign of transitions, openings, and the boundaries between inside and out.
mongamae.position: Surrounds other elements, acting like a frame around the center of the kanji
mongamae.transformsMeaning: Indicates gates, doorways, openings, or concepts related to moving between spaces or being between things

exampleKanji.explanation: Gate radical + hands moving a bolt = the act of swinging the two heavy leaves of a gate open.
Gate radical + a bar or someone inside = the act of pulling the doors together and barring them for the night.
Gate radical + sun (Êó•) = imagine the golden sunlight shining through the tiny gap between the two closed doors of a gate.

mu.name: Mu
mu.origin: The mu radical is a pictograph of a cocoon or a small, enclosed private space. It represents something that is tucked away, "private," or kept strictly out of the public eye and social discourse.
mu.story: Keep it a secret! This radical represents the personal, private details of our lives that we choose not to share with everyone. When you see it, think of self-interest, hidden objects, and the sacred boundaries of your own private world. It brings a sense of intimacy, "exclusive" meaning, and the deep, silent parts of the self to all its characters.
mu.position: Often appears at the bottom or as a central component in complex characters.
mu.transformsMeaning: Indicates privacy or being personal (I/me), secrets and hidden things, self-interest or selfishness, and sometimes formal speech or religious enlightenment.

exampleKanji.explanation: Grain (Á¶æ) + private (Âé∂). It originally referred to the "private" ownership of a "grain" harvest‚Äîeventually coming to mean the individual self or personal property.
A person (‰∫∫) + private/secret (Âé∂). A "person" who has attained a "secret" and profound enlightenment that is hidden from the ordinary world‚Äîrepresenting a Buddha.
Two hands (Âªæ) + private (Âé∂). Originally related to a "hand" carefully adjusting a "private" or specific object‚Äînow used for formal speech and mechanical valves.

mugi.name: Mugi
mugi.origin: The mugi radical is a pictograph of a wheat plant with its ears and stalks clearly visible. It features a "feet" component (Â§ä) at the bottom to represent how these essential grains "come forth" and grow from the fertile earth.
mugi.story: The golden harvest has arrived! This radical represents the staple grains like wheat, barley, and oats that have fueled entire civilizations for millennia. When you see it, think of fresh baking, daily nutrition, and the steady, patient growth of a sun-drenched field. It brings the warmth of the autumn sun and the abundant life-giving energy of the earth to its characters.
mugi.position: Often appears as a standalone kanji or as the main component in complex characters.
mugi.transformsMeaning: Indicates wheat, barley, and other cereal grains, the process of harvesting, flour-based food (noodles), and the fermentation of grains (yeast/koji).

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for the golden cereal grains that are grown in the fields and harvested for food.
Wheat (È∫¶) + surface (Èù¢). Fine "wheat" flour that has been carefully rolled into a thin "surface" or sheet before being cut into long, individual noodles.
Wheat (È∫¶) + grab/hold (Âåä). The specific "wheat" product (koji) that is "grabbed" or prepared to start the essential fermentation process for sake, soy sauce, and miso.

mushi.name: Mushi
mushi.origin: Originally a pictograph of a snake or a worm making its way across the ground. Over time, it came to represent all small crawling and flying creatures, including insects and reptiles.
mushi.story: A wriggly creature moves through the grass! The top part is the head, and the body curves below. While it means 'insect' today, it covers a wide world of small wonders‚Äîfrom spiders and butterflies to snakes and frogs. It represents the small but vital lives that hum all around us.
mushi.position: Standalone kanji, on the left side (mushihen), or at the bottom
mushi.transformsMeaning: Indicates insects, reptiles, small crawling animals, or transformations (like a caterpillar to a butterfly)

exampleKanji.explanation: Insect radical + reaching a peak (Â§Ü) = the busy insect that flies to the peaks of every flower to gather its golden nectar.
Insect radical + work/craft (Â∑•) = in ancient lore, rainbows were thought to be giant silken sky-serpents or 'insects' crafted in the clouds.
Heaven (Â§©) + insect radical = the 'heavenly insect' that provides the world with the miracle of precious silk.

nabebuta.name: Nabebuta
nabebuta.origin: The nabebuta radical is a pictograph of a lid or a cover for a pot or a container. The top vertical stroke represents the handle or the knob, and the horizontal line below it represents the flat surface of the lid itself.
nabebuta.story: Imagine a heavy wooden lid being placed on top of a bubbling iron pot‚Äîthat's nabebuta! When you see this radical at the top of a kanji, think of something that sits on top, covers, or crowns a structure. It brings a sense of enclosure and the idea of being the "head" or the "ceiling" of a character.
nabebuta.position: Always appears at the TOP of the kanji.
nabebuta.transformsMeaning: Indicates a lid, a cover, a high point, or the concept of being situated on top of something else.

exampleKanji.explanation: Lid (‰∫†) + father/cross (Áà∂/Áàª variant). Originally suggested a lid or top being "crossed" or swapped, leading to the meaning of exchange and traffic.
Lid (‰∫†) + mouth (Âè£) + small (Â∞è). Represents a grand building (like a palace or tower) with a high roof‚Äîthe absolute center of a capital city.
Lid (‰∫†) + mouth (Âè£) + pillar/stop. A structure with a high roof where travelers can stop and rest; a classic wooden pavilion.

nagai.name: Nagai
nagai.origin: The nagai radical is a pictograph of an elderly person with long, flowing hair leaning on a staff. The top part represents the hair blowing in the wind, and the bottom horizontal and vertical strokes represent the person and their cane. Because hair continues to grow over time, it became the symbol for "long" and "elder/chief."
nagai.story: Time stretches out like the silver hair of a wise elder! When you see these strokes, imagine a journey that goes on and on, or a leader who has seen many years. It is the radical of endurance and leadership, representing both the physical length of an object and the long-term authority of a chief.
nagai.position: Often appears as a standalone kanji or on the left side of a character.
nagai.transformsMeaning: Indicates physical length, the passage of long periods of time, or the concept of seniority and leadership.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji itself, representing both the quality of being long and the position of a leader or "chief."
Chapeau/top (È´ü) + long (Èï∑). Specifically refers to the long hair on a person's head, emphasized by the "long" radical below.
Bow (Âºì) + long (Èï∑). To pull a bow string "long" until it is fully stretched and ready to fire; also used for spreading out maps or tents.

nakare.name: Nakare
nakare.origin: The nakare radical is a variation of the "mother" radical (ÊØç). It originally depicted a woman with two dots representing breasts, but with an additional horizontal line through the center. This line acted as a "cancel" or "prohibition" sign, changing the meaning from "mother" to "do not" or "must not."
nakare.story: Stop! A strong line is drawn through the center of this character, telling you to halt or cease. While it looks like a mother, that extra stroke turns it into a command of prohibition. When you see this radical, think of a boundary that cannot be crossed or an action that must not be taken. It‚Äôs the radical of limits and caution.
nakare.position: Usually appears as a central component or at the bottom of a character.
nakare.transformsMeaning: Indicates prohibition, negation ("do not"), or related concepts of maternal care and the boundaries within a family.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base form representing a mother nursing a child, the symbol of nurturing, care, and the origin of life.
Person (‰∫∫) + mother/not (ÊØç variant). Originally related to a plant growing or a mother "regularly" tending to things, leading to the meaning of frequency or "every."
Plant (Áîü) + mother/not (ÊØç variant). This refers to a "mother plant" that has grown wild or bitter, becoming "not" good to eat‚Äîa dangerous poison.

natsuashi.name: Natsuashi
natsuashi.origin: The natsuashi radical is a pictograph of a foot pointing downwards, suggesting the action of stepping or treading. It is a variant of the "movement" and "foot" radicals, specifically emphasizing a deliberate or dragging pace, as if someone is walking slowly through the heat of summer.
natsuashi.story: Drag your feet! Imagine the sun beating down so fiercely that you can only take slow, heavy steps. This "summer foot" radical brings the feeling of gradual progress and measured movement to a kanji. When you see it, think of a slow pace, a downward step, or the steady, inevitable movement of time.
natsuashi.position: Always appears at the BOTTOM of the kanji.
natsuashi.transformsMeaning: Indicates slow movement, stepping downwards, the passage of a season, or a sense of deliberate change.

exampleKanji.explanation: Head/page (È†Å) + go slowly (Â§ä). Imagine a person with their face (head) tilted up, walking slowly through the intense heat of the summer sun.
Words (Ë®Ä) + go slowly (Â§ä variant). Originally related to the gradual, sometimes "strange" way that words or situations transform over time.
Mouth (Âè£) + go slowly (Â§ä). Refers to people arriving at a gate or entrance one by one, "each" in their own time and at their own pace.

ni.name: Ni
ni.origin: The ni radical is one of the simplest and most ancient symbols in writing. It consists of two parallel horizontal lines: a shorter one on top and a longer one on bottom. It is a literal representation of the number "two," but it also suggests the concept of duality, balance, and the connection between heaven and earth.
ni.story: One line above, one line below‚Äîa perfect pair! This radical is the foundation of balance and counting. When you see these two lines, think of a duo, a repetition, or the space between two boundaries. It brings the power of symmetry and the basic logic of pluralism to every character it touches.
ni.position: Often appears as a standalone kanji, at the top, or at the bottom of a character.
ni.transformsMeaning: Indicates the number two, duplication, duality, or a sense of layering and horizontal structure.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for the number two, the starting point for all concepts involving pairs, doubles, and duality.
Two (‰∫å) + an intersecting X. Originally represented five through the intersection of the "heaven" and "earth" lines, showing the number five as a central pivot point.
Two (‰∫å) + a swirling shape. Originally depicted swirling clouds in the "two" layers of the sky (heaven and earth), now used as a formal way to say or speak.

nijuuashi.name: Nijuuashi
nijuuashi.origin: The nijuuashi radical is a pictograph of two hands held together or raised up in a gesture of offering, reverence, or cooperation. It represents the strength of two people working in unison or the formal act of presenting something important to a higher authority.
nijuuashi.story: Lift it up together! Imagine two hands reaching out to hold a heavy tray or join together in prayer. This radical is all about cooperation, ceremony, and the shared effort of the human experience. When you see it at the bottom of a kanji, think of an official action, a sacred offering, or the "joining" of forces to achieve a goal.
nijuuashi.position: Always appears at the BOTTOM of the kanji.
nijuuashi.transformsMeaning: Indicates cooperation, ritual offering, formal speech, or actions that require the use of both hands or a group effort.

exampleKanji.explanation: Hands (Âªæ) + a head/hat. Represents a person wearing an official hat, using their "hands" and voice to speak eloquently and defend a position.
Hands (Âªæ) + cloth/broken. Refers to "hands" handling tattered or broken cloth, eventually evolving to mean something harmful, bad, or a humble way to refer to oneself.
Grass (Ëâπ) + death (Ê≠ª) + hands (Âªæ). The formal ceremony of "hands" placing a body beneath the grass‚Äîthe solemn act of a burial.

niku.name: Niku
niku.origin: The niku radical is a pictograph of a slice of meat, specifically showing the internal structure and fibers of the muscle. The outer frame is the boundary of the cut, and the internal strokes represent the layers of flesh and bone within.
niku.story: A juicy cut of meat! This radical represents the physical substance of animal and human life. When you see it, think of strength, nutrition, and the literal "flesh and blood" of a creature. It brings the reality of the biological body and the raw materials of nourishment to the kanji it inhabits.
niku.position: Standalone kanji or appears at the bottom or left (often as nikuzuki) of a character.
niku.transformsMeaning: Relates to physical flesh, food, body parts, biological organs, or the concept of something being "meaty" or substantial.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for meat or the physical body, used in everything from culinary contexts to biological descriptions.
Meat (ËÇâ) + government office (Â∫ú). Imagine meat left sitting in a "government office" for too long‚Äîit eventually begins to rot and decay!
Meat (ËÇâ/Êúà) + delicious (Êó®). This refers to the most "delicious" and flavorful part of the meat‚Äîthe rich, satisfying fat.

nikuzuki.name: Nikuzuki
nikuzuki.origin: The nikuzuki radical is the compressed form of "flesh" (ËÇâ) when it appears on the left side of a kanji. While it looks identical to the "moon" (Êúà), it actually represents muscle and body tissue. The internal strokes represent the fibers of meat, narrowed to sit beside other components.
nikuzuki.story: It looks like the moon, but it's actually muscle! When you see this "moon" on the left side of a character, don't think of the night sky‚Äîthink of your own body. It is the radical of organs, limbs, and physical life. From your heart to your skin, nikuzuki is the building block of the human anatomy in the world of kanji.
nikuzuki.position: Always appears on the LEFT side of the kanji.
nikuzuki.transformsMeaning: Indicates parts of the human body, internal organs, physical conditions, or aspects of biological life and health.

exampleKanji.explanation: Flesh (Êúà) + storage/hide (Ëîµ). The "flesh" that is hidden and "stored" safely inside your body‚Äîyour vital internal organs.
Flesh (Êúà) + sun/bright (ÈôΩ variant). This refers to the long, winding "flesh" of the digestive system that processes the nourishment you take in.
Flesh (Êúà) + desk/table (Âá†). Originally suggested the "flesh" that is as smooth and flat as a wooden table‚Äîthe delicate surface of your skin.

ninben.name: Ninben
ninben.origin: The simplified form of ‰∫∫ (person) when used as a radical on the left side. It shows a person viewed from the side, standing upright with their legs slightly apart.
ninben.story: See the person standing tall, ready to interact with the world! When this radical appears on the left, it signals that the kanji describes a human quality, a social relationship, or an action that people perform. It is the mark of our human presence in the written language.
ninben.position: Always appears on the LEFT side of the kanji
ninben.transformsMeaning: Represents human actions, social statuses, or basic human traits and states of being

exampleKanji.explanation: A person (‰∫ª) leaning against a tree (Êú®) to take a cool, refreshing break from their work.
A person (‰∫ª) + foundation/origin (Êú¨) = the physical body is the foundation and origin of every living person.
A person (‰∫ª) + words (Ë®Ä) = a person standing firmly behind their words; the very heart of trust, belief, and honesty.

nishi.name: Nishi
nishi.origin: The nishi radical is a pictograph of a woven cover or a canopy used to shield something from above. It eventually became associated with the "west" (Ë•ø) because the sun "covers" itself or hides behind the horizon in that direction at the end of the day.
nishi.story: Spread the canopy! This radical represents a protective layer or a lid that wraps over the top of a character. When you see it, think of a shielding cover, a containment, or the direction where the sun goes to rest. It brings a sense of enclosure and the finality of sunset to the characters it joins.
nishi.position: Always appears at the TOP of the kanji.
nishi.transformsMeaning: Indicates a cover, a lid, a state of being contained, or the geographical direction of the west.

exampleKanji.explanation: Cover (Ë•æ) + woman (Â•≥). Originally represented a woman's belt or "cover" for the waist, eventually evolving to mean something "essential" or "important" that holds things together.
Cover (Ë•æ) + fire (Á§∫ variant). Originally suggested bits of sparks or ash "covered" and rising from a fire, now used for slips of paper or ballots.
Cover (Ë•æ) + return/repeat (Âæ© variant). The act of throwing a "cover" over something to hide it, or the sudden "tipping over" (capsizing) of a vessel.

nisui.name: Nisui
nisui.origin: The nisui radical is a simplified form of the "water" radical (Ê∞µ), reduced from three strokes to two. It represents ice crystals or drops of water that have frozen solid, capturing the essence of coldness and the transition from liquid to solid.
nisui.story: Brrr, it's freezing! Imagine two sharp icicles hanging from the edge of a roof. When you see these two strokes on the left side of a kanji, think of winter, freezing temperatures, and the chill of the ice. It brings the power of the "cold" to every character it joins.
nisui.position: Always appears on the LEFT side of the kanji.
nisui.transformsMeaning: Indicates coldness, ice, freezing, the season of winter, or a state of being chilled or solidified.

exampleKanji.explanation: Ice (ÂÜ´) + walking slowly (Â§ä). The season where the world turns to "ice" and life moves "slowly" through the snow.
Ice (ÂÜ´) + command/order (‰ª§). To be "ordered" by the climate to turn into "ice"‚Äîthe literal sensation of something being ice-cold.
Ice (ÂÜ´) + east/sun (Êù±). Imagine the "east" sun trying to rise, but everything is still trapped in a layer of "ice" and frozen solid.

no.name: No
no.origin: The no radical is one of the most fundamental building blocks of Japanese writing. It is a single, elegant diagonal stroke that sweeps from the top-right down to the bottom-left. It originally suggested a curved line, such as a blade of grass or a falling leaf.
no.story: Swoosh! Imagine a single stroke of a brush sweeping across the page like a falling leaf or a gust of wind. This radical is the spirit of movement and direction. When you see it, think of a curve, a change in path, or a single mark that defines the flow of a character. It's the radical of the "sweep."
no.position: Often appears as a central or top component in various characters.
no.transformsMeaning: Indicates movement, direction, a curved path, or acts as a foundational structural element that guides the flow of the kanji.

exampleKanji.explanation: No (‰∏ø) + a support/person. A single "sweep" of time that goes on for a "long duration," suggesting eternity.
No (‰∏ø) + a bowl/container. A single "sweep" that shows a container is empty, representing a state of "scarcity" or being "poor."
No (‰∏ø) + a frame. A single "sweep" within a well or a frame, representing the rare and precious red mineral, cinnabar.

nogihen.name: Nogihen
nogihen.origin: The nogihen radical is a pictograph of a stalk of grain, like rice or wheat, with its head heavy and drooping toward the ground. The top horizontal stroke is the heavy head of grain, the vertical stroke is the stalk, and the diagonal strokes are the leaves.
nogihen.story: The harvest is ready! Imagine a field of golden rice bowing its head in the autumn breeze. This radical is the soul of agriculture and sustenance. When you see it on the left side of a kanji, think of crops, harvests, taxes (which were paid in grain), and the abundance of the earth.
nogihen.position: Always appears on the LEFT side of the kanji.
nogihen.transformsMeaning: Indicates grains (rice, wheat), agriculture, harvesting, wealth/taxation (originally paid in grain), and seasonal changes.

exampleKanji.explanation: Grain (Á¶æ) + fire (ÁÅ´). The season when the "grain" turns the color of "fire"‚Äîthe beautiful golden autumn.
Grain (Á¶æ) + self/private („É†). Originally referred to one's "private" stash of "grain" that was kept for the self, eventually becoming the word for "I."
Grain (Á¶æ) + exchange/release (ÂÖÖ). The "grain" that you must "release" and give to the authority as your formal "tax" payment.

nokanmuri.name: Nokanmuri
nokanmuri.origin: The nokanmuri radical is the "crown" form of the diagonal sweeping stroke (‰∏ø). When it sits on top of a character, it acts as a lid or a directional guide, sweeping across the upper portion of the kanji.
nokanmuri.story: Sweep across the top! This radical is like a tilted lid or a gust of wind blowing over the rest of the character. It provides the initial motion and sets the direction for the strokes below. When you see it at the very top, think of a sudden movement or a curve that defines the entire character's shape.
nokanmuri.position: Always appears at the TOP of the kanji.
nokanmuri.transformsMeaning: Indicates movement from above, a directional shift, or serves as a structural "crown" that flavors the character with a sense of flow.

exampleKanji.explanation: Sweeping stroke (‰∏ø) + a tree (Êú®) + person. Originally depicted a person climbing and "riding" on the top of a wooden structure or tree.
Grain (Á¶æ) + many (Â§ö). While listed here because of its top-left sweep, it shows the "shifting" and "moving" of many grains from one place to another.
Sweeping stroke (‰∏ø) at the top of a shape. It suggests something is being "swept" away until there is almost nothing left‚Äîthe essence of scarcity.

nomata.name: Nomata
nomata.origin: The nomata radical is a pictograph of a pair of legs or a person walking. It is very similar to the "natsuashi" (Â§ä) radical but often emphasizes the act of walking behind or "following" someone else, suggesting a trailing movement.
nomata.story: Walk in my footsteps! Imagine a person walking behind another, following their path. This radical brings the energy of following, chasing, and gradual movement to a kanji. When you see it, think of a sequence, a trailer, or a change that follows another event. It's the radical of the "follower."
nomata.position: Commonly appears at the BOTTOM or in the center of a character.
nomata.transformsMeaning: Indicates following, trailing movement, a sequence of events, or a transformation that results from an earlier action.

exampleKanji.explanation: Words (Ë®Ä) + following/slow (Â§Ç). A situation where "words" are "followed" by a strange or unexpected shift‚Äîthe literal act of changing.
Head (È†Å) + following/slow (Â§Ç). While also associated with natsuashi, it represents the heat that "follows" the spring and makes everyone walk with slow, heavy steps.
Ice (ÂÜ´) + following/slow (Â§Ç). The cold season that "follows" the autumn, bringing ice and slowing down all movement in nature.

oikanmuri.name: Oikanmuri
oikanmuri.origin: The oikanmuri radical is the shortened "crown" form of the full "old" kanji (ËÄÅ). It is a pictograph of an elderly person with long, wispy hair leaning on a staff. In this radical form, the "person" part is flattened to sit on top of other characters.
oikanmuri.story: Respect your elders! This radical is the symbol of wisdom, long life, and the authority that comes with age. When you see it at the top of a kanji, imagine a wise old teacher or a grandparent looking down with experience. It brings a sense of tradition and the weight of many years to any character it joins.
oikanmuri.position: Always appears at the TOP of the kanji.
oikanmuri.transformsMeaning: Indicates old age, wisdom, long experience, physical aging, or the concept of thinking and consideration (as elders are often sought for advice).

exampleKanji.explanation: Old (ËÄÅ) + sun/day (Êó• variant). While its origins are debated, it depicts a "wise" person (elder) who has seen many "days"‚Äînow used as a general suffix for a person.
Old (ËÄÅ) + a breath/effort. To use the wisdom of "age" to "consider" a problem deeply; the act of thinking that leads to a mature decision.
Old (ËÄÅ) + child (Â≠ê). A beautiful symbol of a "child" supporting an "elder"‚Äîthe core virtue of respecting and caring for one's parents.

onna.name: Onna
onna.origin: The onna radical is a pictograph of a woman kneeling or bowing in a traditional posture of respect or seated at a loom. The overlapping strokes represent the arms and legs in a graceful, settled position, capturing the historical role of women in the domestic and social sphere.
onna.story: Grace and strength! This is the radical of the feminine, representing mothers, daughters, and the many roles women have played throughout history. When you see it, think of life, family, and the unique qualities of care and tradition. It is one of the most common radicals, appearing in hundreds of characters related to people.
onna.position: Can appear as a standalone kanji, on the left side (onnahen), or at the bottom of a character.
onna.transformsMeaning: Indicates females, family relationships, emotional qualities, domestic actions, and traditionally feminine roles or names.

exampleKanji.explanation: Woman (Â•≥) + a broom (Â∏ö). Historically referred to a "woman" with a "broom," representing a wife or a mature woman in charge of the household.
Woman (Â•≥) + good (ËâØ). A "good woman" of the family‚Äîthe beloved "daughter" or a young girl full of potential.
Woman (Â•≥) + pedestal/platform (Âè∞). Originally suggested the beginning of life through a "woman," eventually evolving to mean the start of any process or event.

onore.name: Onore
onore.origin: The onore radical is a pictograph of a coiled rope or a bent thread, suggesting something that is personal and focused inward. It eventually evolved to represent the "self" or one's own identity, as if tracing the shape of one's own personal boundaries.
onore.story: Focus on yourself! Imagine a line that curves and bends until it points right back at you. This radical represents the individual, the ego, and the inner life of a person. When you see it, think of self-reflection, personal identity, and the things that belong uniquely to "me."
onore.position: Often appears as a standalone kanji or at the bottom/right of a character.
onore.transformsMeaning: Indicates the self, one's own person, personal boundaries, or the concept of winding and coiling (reflecting its original rope pictograph).

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for one's self, used to emphasize personal identity and the concept of "I" in a formal or humble sense.
Self (Â∑±) + two hands + cloth. To take a "self-contained" piece of cloth or paper and "roll it up" with two hands to create a scroll or volume.
Self (Â∑±) + strike (Êîµ). To take a stick and "strike" one's own "self" to improve habits‚Äîthe literal act of reforming and changing for the better.

onozukuri.name: Onozukuri
onozukuri.origin: The onozukuri radical is a pictograph of a stone axe or a heavy tool used for chopping wood. The vertical and diagonal strokes represent the handle, and the top part represents the heavy, sharp blade ready to strike.
onozukuri.story: Chop! Imagine a heavy axe swinging through the air to split a log. This radical is the symbol of force, separation, and the mastery of raw materials. When you see it on the right side of a kanji, think of cutting, weighing (as axes were used as standard weights), and the creation of something "new" from the old.
onozukuri.position: Always appears on the RIGHT side of the kanji.
onozukuri.transformsMeaning: Indicates chopping, cutting, separation, weighing (units of weight), or the creation of something through forceful action.

exampleKanji.explanation: Axe (Êñ§) + stood up (Á´ã) + wood (Êú®). To use an "axe" to cut "wood" and build something "new" that "stands" tall.
Axe (Êñ§) + a thread/continuity. To take an "axe" and "cut off" the thread of a problem‚Äîthe act of making a final decision or severing a connection.
Wood (Êú®) + axe (Êñ§). To use an "axe" to split "wood" into smaller pieces‚Äîthe literal act of analyzing something by breaking it down.

oogai.name: Oogai
oogai.origin: The oogai radical is a pictograph of a human head, specifically showing the face, eyes, and the crown of the head. It originally represented a person's countenance or the physical head, eventually evolving to mean a "page" because pages in a book were seen as the "heads" or "faces" of the scroll.
oogai.story: Face the world! This radical represents everything that happens from the neck up‚Äîthinking, seeing, breathing, and the very identity of a person. When you see these strokes, imagine a person's face looking back at you. It is the radical of the mind, the leader, and the primary surface of communication.
oogai.position: Always appears on the RIGHT side of the kanji.
oogai.transformsMeaning: Indicates the human head, face, neck, thinking processes, leadership, or the physical surface of a page or document.

exampleKanji.explanation: Command (‰ª§) + head (È†Å). Originally meant the "head" or leader who gives "commands" over a specific land‚Äîthe territory they govern.
Colorful/countenance + head (È†Å). The specific part of the "head" where a person's colorful "expressions" and identity are shown‚Äîthe face.
Bean/vessel (Ë±Ü) + head (È†Å). Compares the human "head" to a sturdy, well-filled container (like a bean vessel) that holds all your thoughts and brains.

oozato.name: Oozato
oozato.origin: The oozato radical is a compressed form of the "village" or "city" kanji (ÈÇë). It is a pictograph of a person kneeling beneath a walled enclosure, representing a settled community or a place where people live under a shared authority.
oozato.story: Welcome to the village! This "big town" radical brings the feeling of community, borders, and organized civilization to a kanji. When you see it on the right side, imagine a busy city street or a quiet country village. It's the radical of geography, settlement, and the places we call home.
oozato.position: Always appears on the RIGHT side of the kanji.
oozato.transformsMeaning: Indicates villages, towns, cities, districts, geographical locations, or the concept of a settled country or community.

exampleKanji.explanation: Two groups of people meeting over food + village (‚ªè). The place where people gather to share a meal and a shared history‚Äîyour "hometown."
Building/person (ËÄÖ) + village (‚ªè). A massive "village" where thousands of "people" and important buildings are gathered‚Äîthe grand capital city.
Gentleman/ruler (Âêõ) + village (‚ªè). A specific "village" or area assigned to a "ruler" or governor‚Äîa regional district or county.

oto.name: Oto
oto.origin: Derived from the speech radical (Ë®Ä), but with an additional mark or change that signifies sound in general‚Äînot just the spoken word, but the music and echoes of the world.
oto.story: A sound emerging from the silence! Unlike 'speech' which is about people's words, 'sound' represents everything audible‚Äîthe music of a flute, the rumble of thunder, or the gentle echoes in a mountain valley. It is the resonance of the universe catching our ear.
oto.position: Standalone kanji or a component within compounds
oto.transformsMeaning: Indicates sounds, noise, music, rhymes, or phenomena that can be heard but not necessarily understood as words

exampleKanji.explanation: Sound + heart (ÂøÉ) = the 'sound' of one's heart translated into a specific purpose or an intended meaning for others to hear.
Sun (Êó•) + sound = the time when the sun has set and you can no longer see your way, leaving your ears as your only guide to the dark world.
Hometown/village (ÈÉ∑) + sound = the sound of the world echoing through the valleys of your homeland, creating a deep resonance.

otsu.name: Otsu
otsu.origin: The otsu radical is a pictograph of a sprouting plant's first shoot as it struggles to push through the hard earth, or a young bird emerging from its shell. Its distinct Z-shape captures the tension and effort of a new life beginning, eventually becoming the rank for "the second."
otsu.story: Push through the barrier! Imagine a tiny sprout winding its way upward, bending and twisting to find the sun. This radical represents effort, potential, and the stage that follows the very first beginning. When you see this curve, think of a life force that is just starting to take shape, winding its way through the world.
otsu.position: Often appears as a standalone kanji or at the bottom/right of a character.
otsu.transformsMeaning: Indicates a secondary rank (second in a series), a budding state, a winding shape, or the concept of effort and potential growth.

exampleKanji.explanation: The number nine, which in its ancient form was related to the winding "Z" of a hand reaching the "end" of the single-digit numbers.
Bird/sprout (‰πô) + claw + child. Originally depicted a mother bird (using its "claw") feeding "milk" or nourishment to its "child" during its early growth (‰πô).
Rising sun (ÂÄù) + winding sprout (‰πô). The sun beating down on a "sprout" until the moisture is gone, leaving the land parched and "dry."

ouhen.name: Ouhen
ouhen.origin: The ouhen radical is identical in shape to the kanji for "king" (Áéã), but when used as a radical on the left side, it actually represents "jewelry" or "precious jade" (Áéâ). It is a pictograph of three pieces of jade strung together on a cord, a symbol of extreme wealth and status.
ouhen.story: A treasure for royalty! While it looks like a "king," the true soul of this radical is "jade." When you see it on the left side of a kanji, imagine the shimmering glow of a precious gem or the clinking of a necklace. It brings a sense of value, beauty, and the "jeweled" quality of anything rare and important.
ouhen.position: Always appears on the LEFT side of the kanji.
ouhen.transformsMeaning: Indicates gemstones (especially jade), jewelry, precious objects, beauty, clarity, and things associated with royalty and high status.

exampleKanji.explanation: Jewel (Áéã) + sword (ÂàÇ) + Jewel (Áéã). To take a large "jewel" and use a "sword" to split it into two equal "groups" or halves.
Jewel (Áéã) + See (Ë¶ã). A hidden "jewel" that is suddenly brought out into the light so that everyone can "see" it‚Äîto appear or be present.
Jewel (Áéã) + Village/order (Èáå). To follow the natural "veins" and "order" inside a rough "jewel" to reveal its true shape‚Äîthe essence of logic and reason.

raisuki.name: Raisuki
raisuki.origin: The raisuki radical is a pictograph of an ancient wooden plow or a "plowing staff." The top horizontal stroke is the handle, the vertical stroke is the main shaft, and the slanted strokes at the bottom represent the sharp blade that turns the earth.
raisuki.story: Break the ground! Imagine a sturdy farmer leaning their weight into a wooden plow, carving deep furrows into the rich soil. This radical is the heartbeat of cultivation and hard work. When you see it, think of the effort required to prepare the land for a future harvest. It‚Äôs the radical of the "toiler."
raisuki.position: Always appears on the LEFT side of the kanji.
raisuki.transformsMeaning: Indicates plowing, farming, preparing the earth, manual labor, or actions associated with agricultural tools.

exampleKanji.explanation: Plow (ËÄí) + a well/frame (‰∫ï). To use a "plow" to prepare the field around a "well" for planting‚Äîthe basic act of farming.
Plow (ËÄí) + hair/tiny (ÊØõ). Originally referred to the "hair-thin" fragments worn away from a "plow" through constant use‚Äîthe act of consuming or wasting resources over time.
Bamboo (Ëâπ variant) + plow (ËÄí) + old. Documents related to the "plowed" land owned by "old" families‚Äîused for property "registers" and census records.

rekka.name: Rekka
rekka.origin: This is an alternate form of the fire radical, showing four flames or embers burning beneath something.
rekka.story: These four dots are flames under a cooking pot! When you see ÁÅ¨ at the bottom of a kanji, imagine a fire heating something from below.
rekka.position: Always appears at the BOTTOM of kanji
rekka.transformsMeaning: Indicates heating, cooking, or being affected by fire

exampleKanji.explanation: Something intensely hot from flames below
Cooking over flames
Light and heat spreading outward

n/a.name: Nonomoji
n/a.origin: The nonomoji („ÄÖ) is not a true kanji, but a specialized symbol used in Japanese to indicate the repetition of the preceding character. It evolved from a simplified form of the character "nijuu" (‰∫å - two), acting as a shorthand for "repeat what was just written."
n/a.story: Double it up! Imagine a quick, elegant mark that tells you to say it again. Instead of writing the same complex kanji twice, this symbol jumps in to save time and add a rhythmic flow to the text. When you see it, think of a mirror reflecting the previous word, doubling its power and meaning.
n/a.position: Always follows the kanji it is repeating.
n/a.transformsMeaning: Indicates pluralization (mountains, people), intensification (sometimes), or a sequence of identical actions or objects.

exampleKanji.explanation: The symbol itself, used to create plurals or emphasize frequency in common Japanese vocabulary.
Mountain (Â±±) + repetition mark („ÄÖ). Instead of just one peak, you have a whole range of "mountains" stretching across the horizon.
Person (‰∫∫) + repetition mark („ÄÖ). A group of individuals gathered together to form "people"‚Äîthe collective essence of humanity.

risshinben.name: Risshinben
risshinben.origin: The risshinben radical is the compressed, "standing" form of the "heart" (ÂøÉ) radical. It represents the human heart and the emotions that pulse from it, narrowed to fit on the left side. The vertical stroke is the core of the heart, with the side strokes representing its rhythmic beating.
risshinben.story: Feel the beat! When the heart "stands up" on the left side of a kanji, it brings the intense energy of emotion and thought. It is the radical of how we feel‚Äîour joy, our hate, our busy minds, and our quiet feelings. When you see it, think of the pulse of your own spirit driving every action you take.
risshinben.position: Always appears on the LEFT side of the kanji.
risshinben.transformsMeaning: Indicates emotions, mental states, temperament, thoughts, feelings, and the inner workings of the human spirit.

exampleKanji.explanation: Heart (‚∫ñ) + increase/layer (Â¢ó variant). An emotion of "hatred" that "increases" and layers upon itself inside the "heart" until it is overwhelming.
Heart (‚∫ñ) + blue/pure (Èùí). The "pure" and foundational "feeling" that comes from the "heart"‚Äîthe essence of human emotion and sympathy.
Heart (‚∫ñ) + perish (‰∫°). A state where your "heart" and mind feel like they are "perishing" or being overwhelmed by too many tasks‚Äîto be Truly busy!

rittou.name: Rittou
rittou.origin: The rittou radical is the compressed "standing" form of the "knife" (ÂàÄ) radical. It represents a sharp, double-edged blade or a sword held upright, ready to cut. It was narrowed to two simple vertical strokes to fit neatly on the right side of characters.
rittou.story: Slice through it! This "standing knife" radical is all about precision and force. Imagine a sharp blade coming down to split something in two. When you see it on the right, think of cutting, dividing, judging, and the decisive action of an edge meeting its mark. It‚Äôs the radical of the "separator."
rittou.position: Always appears on the RIGHT side of the kanji.
rittou.transformsMeaning: Indicates cutting, slicing, carving, separating, judging (deciding a cut), or the use of a sharp tool or weapon.

exampleKanji.explanation: Damaged (ÂÆ≥) + knife (‚∫â). To take something and use a "knife" to "divide" it into sections, often resulting in a "cut" or split.
Thorn/spike (Êúø) + knife (‚∫â). The action of using a "knife" or sharp tool to "pierce" and "stab" through a surface like a thorn.
Half (Âçä) + knife (‚∫â). To take a situation and use a "knife" to cut it exactly in "half"‚Äîto make a clear judgment or decision between two sides.

rumata.name: Rumata
rumata.origin: The rumata radical is a pictograph of a hand (Âèà) holding a heavy weapon, specifically a spiked lance or a cudgel. It represents the forceful application of power and the active process of striking, guiding, or transforming something through physical effort.
rumata.story: Take action! Imagine a hand gripping a sturdy wooden shaft, ready to strike or move an object with force. This radical is the soul of effort and physical change. When you see it on the right side, think of a strong action, a strike, or the heavy "shaft" of a tool being used to accomplish a grand task.
rumata.position: Always appears on the RIGHT side of the kanji.
rumata.transformsMeaning: Indicates physical force, striking, guidance, the use of handheld tools or weapons, or the active "doing" of a complex process.

exampleKanji.explanation: Enclosure/residency + lance shaft (ÊÆ≥). Originally referred to a guarded "palace" where warriors with "lances" stood watch to protect their "lord."
Hand/tool + lance shaft (ÊÆ≥). A violent "action" taken with a "lance" or weapon‚Äîthe literal representation of the act of killing.
Vessel/pot + lance shaft (ÊÆ≥). The act of "striking" a vessel or grain with a "shaft" to remove the outer "shell" or hull.

saji.name: Saji
saji.origin: The saji radical is a pictograph of a spoon or a ladle, specifically showing the curved bowl and the handle. In ancient times, it was also associated with the shape of a person sitting or a knife, leading to its frequent appearance in characters related to transformation and eating.
saji.story: Scoop it up! Imagine a small, elegant spoon ready to serve a delicious meal. This radical represents the tools of nourishment and the act of change. When you see it, think of something being shifted, transformed, or scooped from one state to another. It's the radical of the "ladle."
saji.position: Often appears on the right side or as a central component of a kanji.
saji.transformsMeaning: Indicates tools for eating (spoons), the act of transformation or change, or a seated posture.

exampleKanji.explanation: Person (‰∫∫) + spoon (Âåï). Originally depicted a person turning or flipping over (like a spoon being turned), representing the act of transformation or "becoming" something else.
Two people (Âåï variant) back to back. While it looks like spoons, it represents two people turning away from each other to face the "cold" direction of the north.
Correct/straight (ÊòØ) + spoon (Âåï). The formal kanji for a "spoon," emphasizing the "correct" tool used for eating and serving food.

samurai.name: Samurai
samurai.origin: The samurai radical is a pictograph of an ancient axe or a ceremonial weapon held by a man of status. It originally represented a scholar-official or a warrior who had achieved a certain rank in society. It is distinguished from "earth" (Âúü) by its longer top horizontal stroke.
samurai.story: Stand tall with honor! This radical represents the elite class of society‚Äîthe warriors, scholars, and officials. When you see it, think of a person with specialized skills, a high rank, or the discipline of a samurai. It brings a sense of status, masculinity, and structured authority to the kanji it joins.
samurai.position: Can appear as a standalone kanji, on the left, or at the bottom/center of a character.
samurai.transformsMeaning: Indicates males of high status, scholars, warriors, specific professions, or the concept of vigor and social standing.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for a man of status or a trained professional, used as a suffix for many occupations today (like "attorney" or "scholar").
Samurai (Â£´) + bed/frame. Represents a "man" in the prime of his life, full of energy and "vigor," standing strong like a majestic warrior.
Samurai (Â£´) + mouth (Âè£). Originally referred to the wise "words" spoken by a high-ranking "scholar," which were considered a sign of "good luck" and great joy.

samuraikanmuri.name: Samuraikanmuri
samuraikanmuri.origin: The samuraikanmuri radical is the "crown" form of the "samurai" (Â£´) radical. When it sits on top of a character, it represents the authority and leading role of a scholar or warrior positioned above the rest of the kanji components.
samuraikanmuri.story: The leader at the top! Imagine a high-ranking official or a brave samurai standing on a platform, overseeing their duties. This radical brings the energy of leadership and social status to the very head of the character. When you see it at the top, think of a voice that commands, property that is managed, or a high-ranking position.
samuraikanmuri.position: Always appears at the TOP of the kanji.
samuraikanmuri.transformsMeaning: Indicates a person of status in a leading position, formal actions, authoritative speech, or the quality of being ancient and established.

exampleKanji.explanation: Samurai (Â£´) + a flag/ear variant. Originally suggested the "voice" of a high-ranking "official" (samurai) giving a formal command or announcement.
Samurai (Â£´) + legs/movement. Originally related to a "scholar" or official moving goods or "selling" their services; now the standard kanji for the act of selling.
Samurai (Â£´) + lid + heart variant. The elaborate, "formal" way of writing the number "one," used in legal documents and currency to prevent forgery.

sanbongawa.name: Sanbongawa
sanbongawa.origin: The sanbongawa radical is a pictograph of a flowing river, shown with three vertical (or slightly curved) strokes representing the ripples and currents of the water. "Sanbon" literally means "three pieces," referring to the three distinct lines that make up the character.
sanbongawa.story: Go with the flow! Imagine the rushing water of a great river carving its path through the mountains. These three strokes represent the unstoppable power and grace of liquid in motion. When you see this radical, think of streams, valleys, and the journey of water as it travels toward the sea.
sanbongawa.position: Standalone kanji or appears in the center or on the side of a character.
sanbongawa.transformsMeaning: Indicates rivers, flowing water, natural streams, valleys, or the concept of movement and traveling along a fixed path.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for a river, capturing the essential image of flowing water that has shaped human civilization and the landscape.
River (Â∑ù) + three dots (islands). Reprents "islands" of land settled within a great "river" system‚Äîthe origin of the word for states and provinces.
Movement (Ëæ∂) + river (Â∑õ variant). To move along a path like a "flowing river," following a regular circuit or "patrolling" a specific area.

sanzui.name: Sanzui
sanzui.origin: This radical evolved from the kanji Ê∞¥ (mizu - water). The three strokes represent droplets of water falling or flowing.
sanzui.story: Imagine three raindrops falling‚Äîthat's sanzui! Whenever you see these three dots on the left side of a kanji, think of water, liquids, or anything that flows.
sanzui.position: Always appears on the LEFT side of kanji
sanzui.transformsMeaning: Adds the sense of water, liquid, wetness, or flowing to the kanji's meaning

exampleKanji.explanation: Water + 'every' = the water that's everywhere
Water + long movement = moving through water
Water from the eyes = tears

sanzukuri.name: Sanzukuri
sanzukuri.origin: The sanzukuri radical consists of three parallel diagonal strokes. It is a pictograph representing fine lines, such as a strand of hair, the grain of wood, or the radiant rays of light spreading from a source. It captures the essence of texture and visual appearance.
sanzukuri.story: A touch of elegance! Imagine three fine strokes of a brush adding the final detail to a painting. This radical represents the "look" of a thing‚Äîits texture, its shadow, or the way it reflects light. When you see it on the right side, think of a decorative pattern, a beautiful hairstyle, or the subtle rays of a setting sun.
sanzukuri.position: Always appears on the RIGHT side of the kanji.
sanzukuri.transformsMeaning: Indicates physical appearance, texture (hair, grain), decorative patterns, light rays, or the concept of an image/shadow.

exampleKanji.explanation: Sun/bright (ÊôØ) + three rays (ÂΩ°). The "image" or "shadow" created when the "sun" shines and its "rays" are blocked by an object.
Frame/pattern + three rays (ÂΩ°). The outward "appearance" or "form" of a thing, emphasized by the fine lines that define its visible structure.
Hand + plant + three rays (ÂΩ°). The act of using one's "hand" to apply vibrant "colors" (represented by the light rays) to a surface or object.

sara.name: Sara
sara.origin: The sara radical is a pictograph of a shallow ritual vessel or a serving dish. The outer frame is the rim of the plate, and the internal horizontal stroke represents the food or liquid contained within. It captures the essence of a flat container used for presentation and nourishment.
sara.story: Dinner is served! Imagine a beautiful ceramic plate or a sturdy wooden bowl ready to hold a feast. This radical represents the containers of our lives‚Äînot just for food, but for our efforts and rewards. When you see it at the bottom, think of a vessel, a platform for serving, or the things we "contain" and offer to others.
sara.position: Always appears at the BOTTOM of the kanji.
sara.transformsMeaning: Indicates plates, bowls, vessels, the act of serving food, or the concept of something being "presented" or "contained" on a flat surface.

exampleKanji.explanation: Success/completion + bowl (Áöø). Originally referred to a "bowl" being filled to the brim with food for a feast‚Äînow used to mean "prosperous" or "flourishing."
Desire (Ê¨° variant) + bowl (Áöø). Imagine someone having a hidden "desire" for the "vessel" or contents belonging to another‚Äîthe literal act of stealing.
Divide/split (ÂàÜ) + bowl (Áöø). A flat "vessel" that "divides" or holds items‚Äîthe traditional "tray" used in ceremonies during the O-bon festival.

sato.name: Sato
sato.origin: The sato radical is a combination of "rice field" (Áî∞) and "earth" (Âúü). It originally depicted a settlement or a community of homes built on the ground near the fields‚Äîthe fundamental unit of a "village." It also became a standard unit of distance, representing the length of a typical village.
sato.story: Home is where the fields are! Imagine a cluster of small houses surrounded by rich soil and green crops. This radical represents the heart of rural life and the organized measurement of the landscape. When you see it, think of a community, a hometown, or a long journey through the countryside.
sato.position: Standalone kanji or appears at the bottom or left side of a character.
sato.transformsMeaning: Indicates a village, a hometown, specific measurements of distance, rural fields, or the concept of being settled and established.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji representing a rural settlement or the traditional unit of distance (ri), capturing the essential link between land and community.
Village/distance (Èáå) + offer/give. Originally suggested the open "fields" or "plains" that stretched out beyond the village where crops were grown.
Village/distance (Èáå) + person/pole variant. Originally depicted a person carrying a heavy load over a long "distance"‚Äîthe essence of something being "heavy" or "layered."

shika.name: Shika
shika.origin: The shika radical is a detailed pictograph of a deer. The top part represents the antlers, the middle section is the head and body, and the bottom strokes represent the four legs. It captures the graceful and majestic form of this forest creature.
shika.story: Prance through the forest! Imagine a magnificent stag with branching antlers peering through the trees. This radical represents grace, nature, and the festive elegance of wildlife. When you see it, think of the deep woods, the beauty of the natural world, and the "royal" presence of a deer in the landscape.
shika.position: Often appears as a standalone kanji or as the top/outer component of a character.
shika.transformsMeaning: Indicates deer, wildlife, forest beauty, elegance, or concepts related to jubilation and majestic appearances.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for a deer, used in geography (like Kagoshima or Nara) and to describe the animal itself.
Two antlers (variants) + deer (Èπø). Represents the extreme "beauty" and elegance of two majestic deer standing together‚Äîthe ultimate symbol of loveliness.
Deer (Èπø variant) + heart + movement. Originally related to a "celebration" where a deer was presented as a gift‚Äînow used for great "jubilation" and joy.

shikabane.name: Shikabane
shikabane.origin: The shikabane radical is a pictograph of a person lying down, originally representing a "corpse." However, it also evolved to represent an "awning" or a primitive shelter, as the shape resembles a roof or a covering placed over someone or something.
shikabane.story: Lie down and cover up! This radical has two lives: it can represent the stillness of a body or the protection of a roof. When you see it, think of a person's physical state or a structure that hangs over a space. It‚Äôs the radical of residency, belonging, and the boundaries of a character's enclosure.
shikabane.position: Always appears at the TOP and LEFT of the kanji.
shikabane.transformsMeaning: Indicates a person's body (living or dead), residency/dwelling, awnings/coverings, or the state of belonging to a specific place.

exampleKanji.explanation: Awning/corpse (Â∞∏) + old/ancient (Âè§). Imagine a person "residing" in an "ancient" place for a long time‚Äîto live or be present in a location.
Awning/corpse (Â∞∏) + a chain/tail. Originally suggested things that follow or "belong" together under one roof or awning‚Äîa category or family.
Awning (Â∞∏) + a mouth/boundary. A "governed" space with a roof where official business is conducted‚Äîa bureau or an office department.

shimesu.name: Shimesu
shimesu.origin: The shimesu radical is a pictograph of a stone altar or a table used for religious offerings. The top horizontal line represents the surface of the altar, and the vertical strokes represent the blood or libations dripping down, showing the connection between the human and the divine.
shimesu.story: Make an offering! This radical is the gateway to the sacred world. Imagine a solemn festival at a shrine where an altar is piled high with gifts. It represents the act of "showing" or "revealing" one's intentions to the spirits. When you see it, think of ritual, ceremony, and the power of a formal presentation.
shimesu.position: Standalone kanji or appears at the bottom of a character.
shimesu.transformsMeaning: Indicates religious services, festivals, altars, spirits, the act of "showing" or indicating something, and sacred ceremonies.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for showing or indicating, originally representing the "altar" where divine will was revealed to the people.
Meat + hand + altar (Á§∫). The classic image of a "hand" placing "meat" on an "altar" to "celebrate" a formal festival or rite.
Large + altar (Á§∫). A formal tree or structure used in ceremonies, now primarily known for its use in the sacred city name "Nara."

shimesuhen.name: Shimesuhen
shimesuhen.origin: The shimesuhen radical is the compressed "left side" form of the altar radical (Á§∫). It was simplified to four strokes (Á§ª) to fit beside other components, but it retains the original meaning of a stone altar used for sacred offerings and religious rites.
shimesuhen.story: A blessing on the left! When the altar "steps aside" to the left, it brings the protection of the gods to the character. Imagine the entrance to a quiet shrine where prayers are offered for "luck" and "ancestry." When you see it, think of the spiritual side of life‚Äîblessings, rituals, and the deep connection to your roots.
shimesuhen.position: Always appears on the LEFT side of the kanji.
shimesuhen.transformsMeaning: Indicates divine blessings, ancestors, spirits, religious ceremonies, good luck, and anything associated with sacred rites or shrines.

exampleKanji.explanation: Altar/gods (Á§ª) + a stack/shelf (‰∏î). The "spirits" of those who came before you, honored and "stacked" in the family history‚Äîyour "ancestors."
Altar/gods (Á§ª) + expand/lightning (Áî≥). Represents the "expanding" power of the "spirits" or a "god" revealing themselves like a bolt of lightning.
Altar/gods (Á§ª) + a full jar (Áïê). A "blessing" where the jar (of wine or grain) on the "altar" is completely full‚Äîthe true image of "good luck."

shin.name: Shin
shin.origin: The shin radical is a pictograph of a human eye looking downwards in a gesture of submission or service. The vertical and horizontal lines represent the layers of the eye and eyelid. It eventually evolved to represent a "retainer" or a high-ranking "minister" who serves a ruler.
shin.story: Service with a careful eye! Imagine a trusted advisor or a loyal minister watching over the kingdom with dedicated focus. This radical represents the elite class of servants and officials. When you see it, think of duty, observation, and the specialized role of someone who manages the affairs of a state.
shin.position: Standalone kanji or appears in the center or on the side of a character.
shin.transformsMeaning: Indicates high-ranking ministers, government officials, the act of serving, careful observation, or an official presence at a formal event.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for a government minister or a loyal retainer, the fundamental symbol of civil service and high-ranking duty.
Minister (Ëá£) + goods + person. A formal "minister" or official arriving to "face" a situation or "visit" a site‚Äîto be present at an event.
Minister (Ëá£) + person (‰∫∫). Originally suggested a high-ranking "official" or "person" resting or "lying down" during their duties.

shinnotatsu.name: Shinnotatsu
shinnotatsu.origin: The shinnotatsu radical is a pictograph of a giant clam or a shell from which a creature is emerging, originally representing the concept of vibration or the stirring of life. It eventually became the symbol for the Dragon (the fifth zodiac sign) and the morning hours when life begins to wake.
shinnotatsu.story: Wake up with the dragon! Imagine a majestic dragon stirring in the morning mist between 7 and 9 A.M. This radical represents the energy of growth, the vibration of life, and the beginning of a hard day's work. When you see it, think of agricultural labor, the shaking of a tremor, and the powerful spirit of the zodiac dragon.
shinnotatsu.position: Standalone kanji or appears at the bottom/center of a character.
shinnotatsu.transformsMeaning: Indicates agricultural labor (originally using shells as tools), the morning hours, the dragon zodiac, vibration, shaking, or the stirring of hidden energy.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for the Dragon zodiac sign and the morning hours, capturing the essential energy of emergence and time.
Dragon (Ëæ∞) +Êõ≤ (bent/plow variant). Represents the hard "labor" of "farming" that begins early in the morning and involves bending over the earth.
Hand (Êâå) + dragon (Ëæ∞). To use your "hand" to create a "vibration" or shaking movement‚Äîthe literal act of swinging or shaking.

shinnyou.name: Shinnyou
shinnyou.origin: Combines elements showing a foot and a crossroad, representing the act of walking or traveling along a designated path. Its swooping shape under the kanji suggests the road itself.
shinnyou.story: This swooping radical is the winding road you walk upon! It curves under the rest of the kanji like a path being carved through a landscape. It carries the essence of progress, journeying, and the constant movement of life toward a destination.
shinnyou.position: Always appears at the BOTTOM-LEFT, wrapping under the rest of the character
shinnyou.transformsMeaning: Indicates travel, paths, progress, distance, or the physical act of going toward something

exampleKanji.explanation: Head/leader (È¶ñ) + movement radical = the path where the leader points and where the feet follow; a way of life or a physical road.
Bird (Èöπ) + movement radical = imagine a flock of birds flying forward in a straight, determined line. To move toward a goal.
A robe or enclosure (Ë¢Å) + movement radical = a long, winding path that feels as if you are traveling to the very ends of the earth.

shinyou.name: Shinyou
shinyou.origin: The shinyou radical is a pictograph of a hand holding a branch or a stick. The top part is the branch, and the bottom "cross" (Âèà) represents the hand gripping it. It captures the essence of using a branch for support or as a tool for measurement.
shinyou.story: Lend a helping hand! Imagine holding a sturdy branch to steady yourself as you walk or to prop up a heavy structure. This radical is the symbol of support, delegation, and the many branches of a family or business. When you see it, think of a strong hand providing the stability needed to grow and expand.
shinyou.position: Standalone kanji or appears on the right or bottom of a character.
shinyou.transformsMeaning: Indicates physical support, the branching nature of a tree or organization, financial payment (supporting a cost), or a helping action.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for support and branching, used in everything from "branch offices" to the act of "supporting" a friend.
Tree (Êú®) + branch/support (ÊîØ). The physical "branch" that grows from the trunk of a "tree," providing the structure for leaves and fruit.
Hand (Êâå) + branch/support (ÊîØ). The "support" and dexterity of a "hand" using tools or techniques‚Äîthe essence of specialized "skill."

shiro.name: Shiro
shiro.origin: The shiro radical is a pictograph of a sun rising above the horizon (the single dot at the top), casting a clear, bright light. It represents the color of pure light, cleanliness, and the clarity of a blank surface.
shiro.story: Pure as the morning light! Imagine the very first ray of sun clearing the darkness, leaving everything bright and white. This radical represents honesty, purity, and the beginning of a clear path. When you see it, think of a blank sheet of paper, a cloudless sky, or the innocence of something untouched and new.
shiro.position: Standalone kanji or can appear at the top, bottom, or left of a character.
shiro.transformsMeaning: Indicates the color white, purity, innocence, clarity, truth (speaking openly), or the concept of a blank state or a target.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for the color white, used to describe anything from snow to the "white" of a person's eye or skin.
One (‰∏Ä) + white (ÁôΩ). While its origins are complex, it suggests "one" massive number that is as bright and clear as "white"‚Äîthe number one hundred.
White (ÁôΩ) + spoon/ladle. Represents a bright "white" mark (like a bullseye) that one aims for‚Äînow used for "targets" and as a suffix meaning "characteristic of."

shita.name: Shita
shita.origin: The shita radical is a pictograph of a human tongue poking out of a mouth (Âè£). The top strokes represent the shape of the tongue, and the bottom box is the mouth. It represents the physical organ of taste and the primary tool used for speaking.
shita.story: Watch your language! This radical is the center of communication and flavor. Imagine a tongue moving skillfully to pronounce words or taste a savory meal. When you see it, think of the power of speech, the sharpness of a "tongue-lashing," and the intimate way we express our thoughts through sound.
shita.position: Standalone kanji or appears on the left side of a character.
shita.transformsMeaning: Indicates the physical tongue, taste, speaking, words, communication, or actions involving the mouth and oral expression.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for the tongue, used in biological contexts and in metaphors about speaking and flavor.
Words (Ë®Ä) + tongue (Ëàå). The beautiful combination of "words" and the "tongue" moving together to tell a "story" or have a "talk."
Tongue (Ëàå variant) + spicy/bitter. Originally related to an official "tongue" speaking bitter or formal words to quit a job or define a "word."

shitamizu.name: Shitamizu
shitamizu.origin: The shitamizu radical is a flattened "bottom" form of the "water" radical (Ê∞¥). It was reshaped to sit beneath other components, but it retains the original image of a central stream of water with splashes on either side.
shitamizu.story: Cool water from below! Imagine a clear spring bubbling up beneath a character, providing the life-force needed to grow. While it looks slightly different from the standard "water," it brings the same cooling and nurturing energy. When you see it at the bottom, think of a deep well or a hidden stream flowing under the surface.
shitamizu.position: Always appears at the BOTTOM of the kanji.
shitamizu.transformsMeaning: Indicates water, fluids, nurturing energy, the act of seeking (like finding a spring), or a state of peace and replenishment.

exampleKanji.explanation: Water (Ê∞∫) + a furs/clothes variant. Originally depicted an animal's "pelt" being washed in "water," eventually evolving to mean "seeking" or "demanding" something essential.
Large + water (Ê∞∫) + hands. Represents a person with their hands over a "large" amount of "water," suggesting a calm, "peaceful" state or the name for Thailand.
Grain + water (Ê∞∫). A type of "grain" (millet) that requires plenty of "water" to grow‚Äîa staple of ancient agriculture.

shoku.name: Shoku
shoku.origin: The shoku radical is a pictograph of a lidded vessel full of grain or food. The top part is the lid, and the bottom part represents the container holding the nourishment. It captures the essential human act of gathering and consuming food for survival.
shoku.story: A feast under the lid! Imagine lifting the cover of a steaming pot to find a meal prepared with care. This radical represents the energy of life‚Äînutrition, appetite, and the domestic act of raising food. When you see it, think of the satisfaction of a full stomach and the effort required to "feed" a family or a nation.
shoku.position: Standalone kanji or appears on the left side (shokuhen) of a character.
shoku.transformsMeaning: Indicates food, the act of eating, raising animals (feeding them), nutrition, thirst/drinking, or concepts related to consumption and appetite.

exampleKanji.explanation: Food (È£ü) +Âè∏ (direct/control). The act of "controlling" and providing "food" for animals‚Äîto breed or "raise" livestock.
Sheikh/sheep + food (È£ü). To provide "food" and care for a "sheep" or a child, representing the act of "nurturing" or "fostering."
Food (È£ü) + yawning (Ê¨†). Originally depicted a person opening their mouth (yawning) to take in "liquid food" or "drink" from a vessel.

shou.name: Shou
shou.origin: The shou radical is a pictograph of three small grains of sand or tiny fragments, representing the concept of something being "small" or "minimal." The central vertical stroke is the primary fragment, and the side strokes represent the accompanying pieces.
shou.story: Think small! Imagine three tiny pebbles sitting in the palm of your hand. This radical represents the essence of detail, miniaturization, and the humble beginnings of all things. When you see it, think of "little" amounts, "small" objects, and the subtle precision of being focused on the tiny details.
shou.position: Standalone kanji or can appear at the top, bottom, or center of a character.
shou.transformsMeaning: Indicates smallness, a minimal quantity, youth (a "small" person), detail, or a state of being compact or subtle.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for small, used in everything from "elementary school" to describing the physical size of objects and animals.
Small (Â∞è) + a diagonal stroke. Represents something that is even "smaller" or less than small‚Äîthe concept of having only a "few" or a "little" amount.
