Small (Â∞è) + large (Â§ß). Represents a shape that is "large" at the bottom and "small" at the top‚Äîthe literal image of a "sharp" point or a spire.

shoukanmuri.name: Shoukanmuri
shoukanmuri.origin: The shoukanmuri radical is the "crown" form of the "small" (Â∞è) radical. When it sits on top of a character, its side strokes are often flared outward to accommodate the components below, but it retains the original meaning of something being small, bright, or central.
shoukanmuri.story: The small crown! Imagine a tiny, flickering light or a small cap sitting on top of a character. This radical often brings the energy of "shining" (like light) or "centering" a concept. When you see it at the top, think of a concentrated point of focus, a bright ray, or a small but important leading idea.
shoukanmuri.position: Always appears at the TOP of the kanji.
shoukanmuri.transformsMeaning: Indicates smallness, brightness (light rays), a central point of focus, or used as a structural "crown" for characters related to buildings and light.

exampleKanji.explanation: Small/crown (Â∞è variant) + field/box (Áî∞ variant). Originally related to a "fair" distribution or "hitting" a mark; now used for "the present day" or "success."
Small/crown (Â∞è variant) + a person/legs. Imagine a "person" with "light" or small rays shining from their head‚Äîthe literal image of "light."
Small/crown (Â∞è variant) + earth (Âúü). A grand "building" or "hall" built on the "earth," where the "small" top strokes represent the majestic roof or ornament.

sounyou.name: Sounyou
sounyou.origin: The sounyou radical is a combination of "earth" (Âúü) and a "walking person" (variants). It is a pictograph of a person moving swiftly across the ground, with their arms and legs extended in a rhythmic, energetic pace.
sounyou.story: Pick up the pace! Imagine a runner speeding down a track, their feet barely touching the earth. This radical brings the energy of speed, movement, and "exceeding" boundaries to a kanji. When you see it wrapping around the bottom and left, think of a race, a journey, or the act of surpassing a limit with great effort.
sounyou.position: Wraps around the LEFT and BOTTOM of the kanji.
sounyou.transformsMeaning: Indicates running, swift movement, surpassing/exceeding limits, traveling quickly to a destination, or a state of vigorous action.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for running, capturing the essential motion of a person speeding across the landscape.
Run (Ëµ∞) + calling out (Âè¨). To "run" so fast that you "exceed" the normal limits or "surpass" everyone else‚Äîthe essence of something "super" or "extraordinary."
Run (Ëµ∞) + axe variant (Êàâ). To "run" and use an "axe" to break through a boundary, successfully "crossing over" a mountain or "exceeding" an expectation.

sun.name: Sun
sun.origin: The sun radical is a pictograph of a hand (right side) with a mark (the horizontal stroke) at the pulse point, indicating a specific measurement (about the width of a thumb). It represents the "sun," a traditional unit of length roughly equal to one inch.
sun.story: Measure it out! Imagine a steady hand marking off a tiny distance with care. This radical is the spirit of measurement, precision, and the small rules that hold things together. When you see it, think of a "bit" of something, a tiny unit, or the careful management of a task through "inch-by-inch" progress.
sun.position: Standalone kanji or appears at the bottom or right of a character.
sun.transformsMeaning: Indicates small measurements (inches), precision, law/duty (as laws are "measured" out), ritual, or the concept of a small but significant detail.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for the traditional measurement (sun), used to describe the "size" or "dimensions" of small objects.
Earth (Âúü) + inch/law (ÂØ∏). A place built on "earth" where "laws" and rituals are "measured" out‚Äîthe quiet and orderly space of a "temple."
Vessel + two hands + inch/law (ÂØ∏). The act of holding a sacred "vessel" with "two hands" according to the "law"‚Äîrepresenting "respect" and honor.

sunzukuri.name: Sunzukuri
sunzukuri.origin: The sunzukuri radical is the "right side" form of the "inch" (ÂØ∏) radical. It represents a hand marking a measurement, narrowed and positioned to govern the action or state of the character from the right.
sunzukuri.story: The marking hand! Imagine eyes watching as a hand marks a legal seal or measures a boundary. This radical brings the energy of precision and "duty" to a kanji. When you see it on the right, think of a rule being followed, a letter being sealed, or the steady "patience" required to measure out a long task.
sunzukuri.position: Always appears on the RIGHT side of the kanji.
sunzukuri.transformsMeaning: Indicates duty, legal actions (seals), measurement from a distance, or the concentrated effort and patience needed to complete a task.

exampleKanji.explanation: Mound/earth + inch (ÂØ∏). The act of "measuring" out a mound of earth to "seal" a letter or create a formal "enclosure."
Beard/face + inch (ÂØ∏). Originally related to a legal punishment (shaving a beard), eventually evolving to mean the "measured" patience needed to "endure" a hardship.
Culture/clump + inch (ÂØ∏). To "measure" one thing "versus" another, creating a pair of "opposites" or a balanced comparison.

ta.name: Ta
ta.origin: The ta radical is a literal pictograph of a rice paddy viewed from above. The square frame represents the boundaries of the field, and the internal cross (ÂçÅ) represents the dikes or paths that divide the field into four smaller sections for irrigation and management.
ta.story: The lifeblood of the village! Imagine a patchwork of green rice fields stretching across a fertile valley. This radical represents the hard work of the farmer, the bounty of the earth, and the organized structure of agricultural society. When you see it, think of wealth, land, and the rhythmic cycle of the planting and harvest seasons.
ta.position: Standalone kanji or can appear at the top, bottom, or center of a character.
ta.transformsMeaning: Indicates rice fields, land, agricultural work, physical strength (man in the field), wealth, and the organization of space for production.

exampleKanji.explanation: Rice field (Áî∞) + top/lid + clothes/fur. Originally related to piling up or "folding" items in the fields, now representing the traditional straw "tatami" mats that measure the size of a room.
Rice field (Áî∞) + nail/block (‰∏Å). Represents an area divided into specific "blocks" or "rice fields" where people settled together‚Äîthe origin of a small "town."
Rice field (Áî∞ variant/heart) + heart (ÂøÉ). Originally depicted the brain (shaped like a field) and the "heart" working together to "think" and process memories.

tahen.name: Tahen
tahen.origin: The tahen radical is the "left side" form of the rice paddy radical (Áî∞). While it looks like the standard field, it is narrowed and positioned to define the action or attribute of the character from the left, emphasizing its role as the foundation of land and labor.
tahen.story: Grounding on the left! When the rice field moves to the side, it sets the stage for characters related to strategies, boundaries, and the literal soil we walk on. Imagine a row of well-tended fields lining the path. It represents the starting point for organize labor and the careful planning required to manage a great estate.
tahen.position: Always appears on the LEFT side of the kanji.
tahen.transformsMeaning: Indicates agricultural strategies, boundaries, territory, land-based labor, or the concept of something being "abbreviated" (like a map of fields).

exampleKanji.explanation: Field (Áî∞) + each/every (ÂêÑ). To divide "each" part of the "fields" according to a specific plan‚Äîthe essence of a "strategy" or an "abridged" summary of land.
Field (Áî∞) + strength (Âäõ). The classic representation of a "man" using his "strength" to work in the "rice fields"‚Äîthe defining role of traditional masculinity.
Field (Áî∞) + fire (ÁÅ´). Represents a dry "field" created through the "fire" of clearing land (slash-and-burn), specifically used for crops that don't require flooded paddies.

takai.name: Takai
takai.origin: The takai radical is a pictograph of a multi-story building or a watchtower. The top part represents the high roof, the middle "mouth" (Âè£) represents a window or a room, and the bottom section represents the foundation or a gate. It captures the essence of height and physical elevation.
takai.story: Look up at the towers! Imagine a grand tower rising high above the city walls, reaching for the clouds. This radical represents seniority, price, and anything that stands tall and proud. When you see it, think of a prestigious building, a high mountain, or the sense of something being "expensive" and out of reach for many.
takai.position: Standalone kanji or appears as a central component of a character.
takai.transformsMeaning: Indicates physical height, high prices/costs, status, seniority, tall structures (towers/pavilions), or the concept of excellence and being "above" others.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for height and cost, used to describe everything from tall mountains to the "high" status of a senior official.
Person (‰∫ª) + pavilion (‰∫≠ - high building). Originally a "person" reaching a "high building" or pavilion to rest‚Äîthe literal act of "stopping" or halting.
Lid + High (È´ò variant). Originally depicted a "high" structure (like a palace) that was the "head" or center of the kingdom‚Äîthe absolute capital city.

take.name: Take
take.origin: The take radical is a pictograph of two stalks of bamboo with their leaves hanging down. The vertical strokes are the segments of the bamboo, and the small diagonal strokes at the top are the slender, drooping leaves.
take.story: Flexible and strong! Imagine a thicket of green bamboo swaying in the wind, bending but never breaking. This radical represents the versatility of natural materials‚Äîused for everything from food and construction to writing tools and musical instruments. When you see it, think of resilience, tradition, and the countless ways nature provides for humanity.
take.position: Standalone kanji or appears at the top (takekanmuri) of a character.
take.transformsMeaning: Indicates bamboo, objects made of bamboo (boxes, mats, flutes), writing tools (brushes), or the qualities of being flexible, light, and durable.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for bamboo, the heart of Asian culture and a symbol of integrity and growth.
Bamboo (‚∫Æ) + tree/each. Represents a "box" or container originally woven or constructed from "bamboo" for storage and transport.
Bamboo (‚∫Æ) + young/distorted (Â§≠). Imagine a person bending like "bamboo" in the wind as they "laugh" or "smile" with joy.

takekanmuri.name: Takekanmuri
takekanmuri.origin: The takekanmuri radical is the "crown" form of the bamboo radical (Á´π). It represents the same two stalks with drooping leaves, but flattened and positioned on top to show that the character below is related to objects made from or inspired by bamboo.
takekanmuri.story: Under the bamboo canopy! This radical brings the practicality and craftsmanship of bamboo to the head of many kanji. When you see it at the top, think of brushes, baskets, ancient documents (written on bamboo strips), and the clever plans and policies that keep a society moving forward.
takekanmuri.position: Always appears at the TOP of the kanji.
takekanmuri.transformsMeaning: Indicates tools, documents, instruments, or objects specifically made of bamboo, as well as concepts like planning, measuring, and answering.

exampleKanji.explanation: Bamboo (‚∫Æ) + a thorny branch/whip. Originally referred to a "bamboo" whip used to guide horses, eventually evolving to mean a "plan" or "strategy" used to guide a project.
Bamboo (‚∫Æ) + hand holding things. The classic image of a "hand" holding a handle made of "bamboo" with hairs attached‚Äîthe primary tool for writing.
Bamboo (‚∫Æ) + fit/join (Âêà). To "fit" a "bamboo" strip into its matching piece‚Äîthe literal act of "joining" two parts to provide a correct "answer."

takumi.name: Takumi
takumi.origin: The takumi radical is a pictograph of a carpenter's square or a tool used for measurement and construction. The top and bottom horizontal lines represent the two parallel surfaces, and the vertical line represents the connection between them, showing the "work" required to join materials.
takumi.story: Master your craft! Imagine a skilled builder using a carpenter's square to ensure every corner of a new home is perfect. This radical represents the essence of manual labor, engineering, and the "skill" of the craftsman. When you see it, think of construction, industry, and the dedicated effort of someone who works with their hands and mind.
takumi.position: Standalone kanji or can appear at the top, bottom, or center of a character.
takumi.transformsMeaning: Indicates work, labor, construction, engineering, craftsmanship, industry, or the concept of creating something through skilled manual effort.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for work and industry, used in everyday words like "construction" (Â∑•‰∫ã) and "factory" (Â∑•Â†¥).
Hand (†Çá) + work/tool (Â∑•). Historically, the "left" hand was seen as the one holding the "work" or tool while the right hand performed the primary action.
Plant/branch + work/tool (Â∑•). Originally suggested the "work" of separating plants, eventually evolving to mean the "gap" or "difference" between two things.

tama.name: Tama
tama.origin: The tama radical is a pictograph of three precious stones (jade) strung together on a cord, with a single dot added to distinguish it from the "king" (Áéã) radical. It represents anything round, precious, or gemstone-like, capturing the essence of value and beauty.
tama.story: Treasure in your hand! Imagine holding a perfectly round, shimmering jade ball or a string of precious gems. This radical represents the most valuable objects in nature‚Äîjewels, pearls, and even the "ball" used in a game. When you see it, think of beauty, rarity, and the "royal" quality of anything that is precious to behold.
tama.position: Standalone kanji or appears at the bottom or left (often as ouhen Áéã) of a character.
tama.transformsMeaning: Indicates gemstones, jewels, round objects (balls), precious items, value, or things associated with high status and beauty.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for a gemstone or any round object, used for everything from "pearls" to the balls used in sports and games.
Jewel (Áéã) + hair/texture. Represents a "jewel" with a unique and "curious" texture‚Äîsomething that is "rare" and hard to find.
Jewel (Áéã) + vermillion/red. Originally referred to a precious "pearl" or "gem" that had a vibrant, beautiful color and perfect round shape.

tani.name: Tani
tani.origin: The tani radical is a pictograph of water flowing down from a mountain (the top inverted 'V' strokes) and collecting in a basin or mouth (the bottom Âè£). It represents the natural formation of a "valley" or a ravine where water gathers and life thrives.
tani.story: Deep in the canyon! Imagine the cool, shaded space between two high mountain peaks where a stream flows quietly along. This radical represents the low points of the landscape where everything eventually gathers. When you see it, think of wide open spaces, deep ravines, and the sense of something "hollow" or reaching deep into the earth.
tani.position: Standalone kanji or appears on the left or bottom of a character.
tani.transformsMeaning: Indicates valleys, ravines, deep spaces, the act of gathering or containing, or concepts related to desire (reaching for something deep) and admission.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for a valley or mountain stream, a symbol of the natural beauty and the geological "low points" of the world.
Valley (Ë∞∑) + yawning (Ê¨†). Imagine a "valley" that is empty and "yawning" for something to fill it‚Äîthe literal image of a deep "desire" or want.
House (ÂÆÄ) + valley (Ë∞∑). A "house" that is as spacious as a "valley," able to "contain" or "admit" many people and things‚Äîalso used for outward appearance.

tatebou.name: Tatebou
tatebou.origin: The tatebou radical is one of the simplest strokes in the Japanese language‚Äîa single vertical line drawn from top to bottom. It represents a staff, a pole, or the "spine" of a character, providing the vertical axis around which other components are built.
tatebou.story: Stand straight! Imagine a single, strong pillar or a walking staff that holds everything together. This radical is the spirit of verticality and central focus. When you see it, think of a line that pierces through a space, a boundary that divides left from right, or the steady, upright presence that defines a character's core.
tatebou.position: Usually appears as a central stroke or a structural guide within various characters.
tatebou.transformsMeaning: Indicates a central axis, a division, verticality, a staff/pole, or provides the foundational structure that "pierces" through other components.

exampleKanji.explanation: Vertical stroke (‰∏®) + a mouth/box (Âè£). The literal image of a line "piercing" through the very "middle" of a space‚Äîthe essence of being inside.
Vertical stroke (‰∏®) + sun (Êó•). Originally represented a branch or marker blocking the "sun," eventually evolving to mean something "ancient" or "former."
Vertical stroke (‰∏®) + two boxes (Âè£). The perfect pictograph of a wooden "skewer" piercing through two pieces of food‚Äîthe literal act of skewering.

tatsu.name: Tatsu
tatsu.origin: The tatsu radical is a pictograph of a person standing firmly on the ground. The top horizontal stroke is the head, the middle part represents the arms or shoulders, and the bottom horizontal line is the ground upon which the person "stands" or "establishes" themselves.
tatsu.story: Rise and stand! Imagine a person standing tall and proud, rooted to the earth with purpose. This radical is the heart of independence, establishment, and the physical act of being upright. When you see it, think of starting a project, building a structure from the ground up, and the strength of character needed to stand your ground.
tatsu.position: Standalone kanji or appears at the top or left of a character.
tatsu.transformsMeaning: Indicates standing, establishing, starting, independence, being upright, or concepts related to sound (standing at a distance to hear) and darkness.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for standing, the foundation for all concepts involving being upright, independent, or starting a new endeavor.
Stand (Á´ã) + sun/mouth (Êó•). Imagine a sound that "stands" alone in the air, or the "mouth" producing a tone that carries across a distance‚Äîthe essence of music.
Sun (Êó•) + sound (Èü≥). The state where the "sun" has gone down and only "sounds" can be heard in the "darkness"‚Äîthe absence of light.

tatsuhen.name: Tatsuhen
tatsuhen.origin: The tatsuhen radical is the "left side" form of the stand radical (Á´ã). It was narrowed to fit beside other components, but it retains the original image of a person standing firmly on the ground, representing the act of establishing a position or reaching an edge.
tatsuhen.story: Standing on the side! When the "stand" radical moves to the left, it brings the energy of competition, limits, and finality. Imagine a row of people standing at a starting line or at the very edge of a cliff. It represents the boundary where one thing ends and another begins, and the effort required to "stand" against an opponent.
tatsuhen.position: Always appears on the LEFT side of the kanji.
tatsuhen.transformsMeaning: Indicates a position, an end/edge, a boundary, competition (two standing together), or the act of reaching a final state or limit.

exampleKanji.explanation: Stand (Á´ã) + special/direct (ËÄë). The very "edge" or "end" where something "stands" apart from the rest‚Äîthe side of a table or the terminal of a line.
Two "stands" (Á´ã) + two people (ÂÖÑ variant). The literal image of two people "standing" side-by-side to "compete" or see who is faster‚Äîthe essence of a race.
Stand (Á´ã) + a hollow/exhaustion. To reach the very "end" or limit where one can no longer "stand"‚Äîthe act of completely exhausting a resource.

te.name: Te
te.origin: The te radical is a pictograph of a human hand with five fingers spread out. The central vertical stroke is the wrist and palm, and the horizontal and diagonal strokes represent the fingers ready to grip, touch, or perform a task.
te.story: Lend a hand! This radical is the ultimate symbol of human action and creativity. Everything we build, write, and play begins with our hands. When you see it, think of skill, care, and the physical mastery of the world around us. It is the radical of the "maker," the "player," and the "doer" in every story.
te.position: Standalone kanji or appears at the bottom or left (as tehen Êâå) of a character.
te.transformsMeaning: Indicates hands, physical actions (grip, throw, take), skill, manual labor, physical touch, or a person who performs a specific role (like a player).

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for the human hand, the starting point for all concepts involving touch, action, and specialized skill.
Hand (Êâã) + eye (ÁõÆ). To place your "hand" over your "eyes" like a visor to better "watch" or "see" someone in your care‚Äîthe essence of nursing.
Hand (Êâã) + a structure. To use your "hand" to "raise" or lift something up, as in raising your hand to vote or "elect" a leader.

tehen.name: Tehen
tehen.origin: A simplified, compressed form of Êâã (hand). It is condensed into three quick strokes to fit perfectly on the left side of a kanji, representing human agency and action.
tehen.story: Imagine a hand reaching out from the left to grab, hold, or shape the world! When you see these three strokes, think of a hand in motion. It tells you the kanji involves an action‚Äîsomething being made, hit, measured, or manipulated by human effort.
tehen.position: Always appears on the LEFT side of the kanji
tehen.transformsMeaning: Indicates physical actions, especially those performed with the hands or involving manual labor and skill

exampleKanji.explanation: Hand radical (Êâå) + temple/measure (ÂØ∫) = a hand holding onto something with the same stability and care as a sacred temple.
Hand radical (Êâå) + join/fit (Âêà) = the action of hands coming together to gather items from the earth and pick them up.
Hand radical (Êâå) + nail/stake (‰∏Å) = imagine the motion of a hand striking a nail or a hammer hitting a stake firmly into the ground.

ten.name: Ten
ten.origin: The ten radical is a single, small mark‚Äîthe simplest element of Japanese writing. It represents a drop of liquid, a tiny seed, or a point of emphasis added to a character to modify its meaning or distinguish it from a similar form.
ten.story: The power of a single point! Imagine a single drop of ink falling onto a page, or a tiny spark of light in the darkness. This radical represents the smallest unit of focus and change. When you see it, think of a detail that makes all the difference‚Äîlike the flame on a lamp or the unique mark that identifies a master.
ten.position: Usually appears at the top or within the body of a kanji.
ten.transformsMeaning: Indicates a point of focus, small objects (seeds/drops), emphasis, or used as a distinguishing mark to change the meaning of a base character.

exampleKanji.explanation: Dot (‰∏∂) + king (Áéã). Imagine a lamp with a single "dot" representing the flame‚Äîoriginally meaning the "master" or the central "main" point of a household.
Nine (‰πù) + dot (‰∏∂). Originally suggested a shape that has been rounded off or "completed" with a final "dot"‚Äîthe essence of a perfect circle.
Casing + dot (‰∏∂). Represents a piece of "vermillion" ore or a precious red stone (the "dot") contained within a mine‚Äîthe origin of the bright red color.

to.name: To
to.origin: The to radical is a pictograph of a single-leaf door, specifically a wooden door hanging on a hinge. The top horizontal stroke is the header, the left vertical stroke is the jamb, and the internal strokes represent the panel of the door itself.
to.story: Knock on the door! Imagine the wooden door of a traditional house swinging open to welcome a guest. This radical represents the home, the private space of a household, and the act of entering or leaving a room. When you see it, think of the boundaries of a family, the protection of a dwelling, and the many stories that happen behind closed doors.
to.position: Standalone kanji or appears at the top or left of a character.
to.transformsMeaning: Indicates doors, households, family units, private spaces, or concepts related to returning home or covering a room.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for a door, also used to count "households" in a census or family register.
Door (Êà∏) + large/person. Originally suggested a "person" coming back through the "door" after a long journey‚Äîthe act of returning.
Door (Êà∏) + direction/side (Êñπ). Represents a "side room" or a small "chamber" within a house‚Äînow also used for clusters or "tassels" of items.

tobu.name: Tobu
tobu.origin: The tobu radical is an elaborate pictograph of a bird in flight. The central vertical part is the body, and the intricate strokes on the sides represent the outstretched wings and the ruffling of feathers as the bird soars through the air.
tobu.story: Take to the skies! Imagine a majestic bird spreading its wings and catching an updraft, rising higher and higher above the mountains. This radical is the ultimate symbol of flight, speed, and reaching great heights. When you see it, think of the freedom of the air, the roar of an airplane, and the amazing energy required to defy gravity.
tobu.position: Standalone kanji or appears as a primary component of a character.
tobu.transformsMeaning: Indicates flying, rapid movement through the air, airplanes, high altitude, or the concept of things that "fly" or move with extreme speed.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for flight, capturing the essential motion of birds and anything that travels through the sky.
Fly (È£õ) + movement + machine. The "machine" that uses the power of "flight" and "movement" to travel across the world‚Äîa literal flying machine.
Fly (È£õ) + movement + place. The specialized "place" where birds and "flying" machines take off and land‚Äîa modern airport.

todare.name: Todare
todare.origin: The todare radical is the "hanging roof" or "top-left" form of the door radical (Êà∏). It represents the same single-leaf door, but it is reshaped to provide a protective "awning" over the other components of the kanji.
todare.story: Under the door's protection! Imagine a character seeking shelter under the overhang of a sturdy wooden door. This radical brings the energy of a specific location or a physical "place" to the kanji. When you see it hanging from the top-left, think of an address, a base of operations, or the protective boundaries of a household.
todare.position: Always appears at the TOP and LEFT of the kanji.
todare.transformsMeaning: Indicates specific places, addresses, households, shoulders (as the "hinge" of the arm), or the concept of a focused location or area.

exampleKanji.explanation: Door/roof (Êà∏) + an axe variant. Originally related to the sound of an "axe" working on a "door," now the standard kanji for a "place" or an "address."
Door/roof (Êà∏) + flesh/body (Êúà). The "shoulder" is the "hinge" of the "body" (flesh), just as a "door" is the hinge of a room‚Äîthe part where the arm "hangs."
Door/roof (Êà∏) + feathers/wings (ÁæΩ). A "fan" moves back and forth like a "door" swinging on its hinge, originally made from "feathers."

tomeru.name: Tomeru / Shi
tomeru.origin: A pictograph of a human foot at rest. The top strokes represent the toes pointing upward, and the bottom horizontal shows the heel planted firmly on the ground.
tomeru.story: Stop right there! See the foot planted firmly on the earth. The character shows the toes pointing upward, indicating that the person has ceased their journey and is now standing perfectly still. It represents boundaries, the end of a path, and the moment of pausing.
tomeru.position: Standalone kanji or positioned at the bottom or within other characters
tomeru.transformsMeaning: Indicates stopping, staying, ceasing motion, or reaching a boundary or conclusion

exampleKanji.explanation: Stop (Ê≠¢) + a simplified foot (Â∞ë form) = the rhythmic cycle of stepping forward and stopping; the physical act of walking.
One (‰∏Ä) + stop = stopping exactly at the 'one' right place; the quality of being true, correct, and just.
Cliff/building (ÂéÇ) + stop = the stopping points of time as they pass through the great events and structures of human history.

tori.name: Tori
tori.origin: A detailed pictograph of a bird in profile. You can clearly see the head with its eye, the wings tucked in the middle, and the tail feathers fanning out at the bottom.
tori.story: See the bird perched on a branch, ready to take flight! The top horizontal line is the head, the box with a dot is the sharp eye, and the strokes below show the beautiful feathers of the wings and tail. It capture the elegance and freedom of all winged creatures that soar through the sky.
tori.position: Standalone kanji or typically on the right side of compounds
tori.transformsMeaning: Indicates birds, flying creatures, the act of chirping or singing, or things related to flight

exampleKanji.explanation: Mouth (Âè£) + bird = the image of a bird opening its mouth wide to greet the morning sun with a song or a cry.
Bird + nine (‰πù) = a clever character where 'nine' represents the cooing sound of a pigeon, which sounds like 'ku' in Japanese.
Bird radical + a high, rising element = the elegant, long-necked bird that stands tall in the marshes and flies toward the heavens.

tsu.name: Tsu
tsu.origin: The tsu radical consists of three small marks at the top of a character that resemble the Katakana character "tsu" („ÉÑ). It is a simplified version of more complex ancient forms representing light, sparks, or the roof of a decorative building.
tsu.story: Three sparks at the top! Imagine three small flickers of light or raindrops falling onto the roof of a house. This radical represents small, intense points of focus. When you see it at the very top of a character, think of the "sparks" of a strict discipline, the busy energy of management, or the simple "unit" that makes up a larger whole.
tsu.position: Always appears at the TOP of the kanji.
tsu.transformsMeaning: Indicates small parts, intense focus, light rays/sparks, strictness, or provides the structural "crown" for characters related to management and simplicity.

exampleKanji.explanation: Tsu crown (‚∫ç) + a field + a box. Originally suggested a "single" weapon or tool with multiple points, now used for things that are "simple" or "individual."
Tsu crown (‚∫ç) + two boxes (Âè£) + cloth/bottom. Represents the busy, "sparking" activity of "managing" a large building or running a business office.
Tsu crown (‚∫ç) + cliff/rock + dare. A "severe" and "strict" attitude, as intense as "sparks" flying from a "cliff" or a difficult task.

tsuchi.name: Tsuchi
tsuchi.origin: A pictograph showing a mound of earth or the surface of the ground. The bottom horizontal line is the earth's surface, and the cross represents soil piled up or a sprout emerging.
tsuchi.story: Imagine a cross planted firmly in the ground‚Äîthat's Âúü! It shows a stake or a seedling marking the earth, reminding us of farming, construction, and the solid foundation upon which we build our lives and cities.
tsuchi.position: Standalone kanji, on the left side (tsuchihen), or at the bottom
tsuchi.transformsMeaning: Relates to the ground, soil, specific locations, or the act of building and construction

exampleKanji.explanation: Earth radical + also (‰πü) = the actual physical ground we stand on and walk across.
Earth radical + change/spread (Êòú) = a designated piece of land where something specific happens.
Earth radical + return/back (Âèç) = land that rises up and forces you to work hard to climb‚Äîa slope.

tsuki.name: Tsuki
tsuki.origin: The tsuki radical is a pictograph of a crescent moon with two horizontal clouds drifting across it. It represents the night sky, the rhythm of the months, and the illuminating clarity of the moonlight. Note: On the left side, it often becomes "nikuzuki" (flesh), but as "tsuki," it remains focused on time and light.
tsuki.story: The silver glow of the moon! Imagine the quiet beauty of a full moon rising over a dark horizon, marking the passage of time. This radical represents the cycles of the month and anything that is bright, clear, and hopeful. When you see it, think of "good news," the "period" between seasons, and the "cheerful" light that guides us through the night.
tsuki.position: Standalone kanji or appears on the right or bottom of a character.
tsuki.transformsMeaning: Indicates the moon, months, periods of time, brightness/clarity (reflecting moonlight), hope, and feelings of cheerfulness or looking forward.

exampleKanji.explanation: Good/good (ËâØ) + moon (Êúà). To be as "good" and "bright" as the "moon" in the night sky‚Äîrepresenting a "cheerful" and clear personality.
Month/moon (Êúà) + a base/foundation. A specific "period" or "month" that has been set as a foundation‚Äîthe time of an "expectation" or deadline.
Moon (Êúà) + king + looking person. A person (the king) "looking" at the "full moon" and making a "wish" or "hoping" for a bright future.

tsukurigawa.name: Tsukurigawa
tsukurigawa.origin: The tsukurigawa radical is a pictograph of an animal hide stretched out to be tanned. The top and bottom parts represent the head and tail/rest of the hide, and the middle section shows the skin being pulled and scraped to prepare it for use. It captures the essence of raw material being transformed into durable leather.
tsukurigawa.story: Stretch it tight! Imagine a tough piece of animal hide being carefully prepared by a master tanner. This radical represents the transformation of nature into something protective and long-lasting‚Äîthe leather used for shoes, armor, and belts. When you see it, think of durability, the smell of a tannery, and the hard "revolution" of changing a raw material into a refined product.
tsukurigawa.position: Standalone kanji or appears on the left side of a character.
tsukurigawa.transformsMeaning: Indicates leather, hide, shoes, protective gear, the act of tanning/scraping, or concepts related to reform and "revolution" (changing layers/skins).

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for leather, also famously used for "revolution" (ÊîπÈù©), representing a fundamental change to the very "skin" or structure of a system.
Leather (Èù©) + turn/change. The primary footwear made of "leather" (shoes), which allow you to "turn" and move your feet across the ground with protection.
Leather (Èù©) + wrap/envelop (ÂåÖ). A container made of "leather" used to "wrap" and carry your belongings‚Äîthe modern briefcase or bag.

tsuno.name: Tsuno
tsuno.origin: The tsuno radical is a pictograph of an animal's horn. The top part is the pointed tip, and the bottom "mouth" (Âè£) represents the base where it attaches to the skull. It captures the essence of something sharp, protruding, and used for both defense and as a tool for measurement.
tsuno.story: Sharp and sturdy! Imagine the curved horn of a bull or a goat, used to mark territory or as a cup for drinking. This radical represents the sharp "corners" of the world and the "senses" we use to touch and perceive our surroundings. When you see it, think of an angle, a protruding point, and the direct "contact" someone makes with an object.
tsuno.position: Standalone kanji or can appear on the left or top of a character.
tsuno.transformsMeaning: Indicates horns, corners, angles, physical contact (touch), perception (senses), or used as a measurement of degree and position.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for a horn or a corner, used in geometry for "angles" and in daily life for the "corners" of a box or a street.
Horn (Ëßí) + insect/worm. Originally suggested an insect using its "horns" (antennae) to "touch" and sense its environment‚Äîthe act of physical contact.
Horn (Ëßí) + knife (ÂàÄ) + cow (Áâõ). To use a "knife" to separate the "horns" of a "cow"‚Äîthe literal image of "untieing" a complex problem to reach an "understanding."

tsutsumigamae.name: Tsutsumigamae
tsutsumigamae.origin: The tsutsumigamae radical is a pictograph of a person bending over to wrap or cradle something in their arms. It represents the act of surrounding or "enveloping" an object to protect it or hold it together.
tsutsumigamae.story: Keep it safe! Imagine reaching out to wrap a warm blanket around a friend or carefully "enclosing" a gift in paper. This radical is the spirit of protection and containment. When you see it wrapping around the top and right, think of a bandage, a kitchen knife (contained in its sheath), or the "encompassing" nature of a great plan.
tsutsumigamae.position: Wraps around the TOP and RIGHT of the kanji.
tsutsumigamae.transformsMeaning: Indicates wrapping, enveloping, surrounding, protecting, containment, or objects associated with specific packages (like a bandage) or tools.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for wrapping, originally depicting a fetus "enveloped" in the womb‚Äîthe ultimate symbol of containment and protection.
Hand (Êâå) + wrap (ÂåÖ). To use your "hands" to "wrap" around someone‚Äîthe literal act of "hugging" or holding an idea in your heart.
Plant (Ëâπ) + wrap (ÂåÖ) + rice/flower variant. A "plant" whose petals seem to "wrap" or overlap around its center‚Äîthe beautiful chrysanthemum flower.

uji.name: Uji
uji.origin: The uji radical is a pictograph representing a person's lineage or a family name. It originally depicted a tombstone or a landmark indicating the ancestral grounds of a specific clan. It captures the essence of social identity and the deep roots of a family tree.
uji.story: Honor your roots! Imagine a grand monument standing on a hill, marking the territory of a noble family. This radical represents your name, your heritage, and the "clan" to which you belong. When you see it, think of the threads of history that connect you to your ancestors and the sense of belonging that comes from having a strong family identity.
uji.position: Standalone kanji or appears at the bottom or left of a character.
uji.transformsMeaning: Indicates family names, clans, lineage, social titles, or the concept of a fundamental identity or "paper" (as in identity documents).

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for a surname or a courtesy title, representing the foundation of a person's social and historical identity.
Lineage (Ê∞è variant) + eye with a needle (blinded). Originally suggested "people" (subjects) who were blinded and bound to a specific "clan" or master‚Äînow used for the citizens of a nation.
Thread (Á≥∏) + lineage (Ê∞è variant). Represents "paper," which was originally made from leftover "threads" and used to record "family" lineages and official documents.

ukanmuri.name: Ukanmuri
ukanmuri.origin: The ukanmuri radical is a pictograph of a roof with a chimney or a top ornament. The vertical dot at the top is the chimney, and the outer frame represents the overhanging eaves of a traditional home. It is the defining symbol of shelter and domestic life.
ukanmuri.story: Under one roof! Imagine the safety and warmth of a sturdy house at the end of a long day. This radical brings the energy of "home" to every kanji it crowns. When you see it at the top, think of the rooms where we live, the "wealth" we store inside, and the "security" of having a place to call our own.
ukanmuri.position: Always appears at the TOP of the kanji.
ukanmuri.transformsMeaning: Indicates houses, buildings, rooms, shelter, protection, domestic affairs, or concepts related to stability, wealth, and residence.

exampleKanji.explanation: Roof (ÂÆÄ) + full jar (Áïê). A "house" where the storage jars are completely full‚Äîthe literal image of "wealth" and prosperity.
Roof (ÂÆÄ) + woman + tree (Êú®). Originally suggested a "desk" (tree) inside a "house" where one sits to think and create a "plan."
Roof (ÂÆÄ) + movement/bottom. The place where you come to rest at the end of your journey‚Äîyour private "home" or residence.

uma.name: Uma
uma.origin: The uma radical is a detailed pictograph of a horse. The top vertical strokes are the mane, the middle section is the body with four legs (the four dots at the bottom), and the right vertical stroke represents the tail. It captures the power and grace of this essential animal.
uma.story: Gallop ahead! Imagine a spirited stallion charging across a field, its mane flying in the wind. This radical represents speed, transportation, and the "horsepower" that has driven humanity forward for centuries. When you see it, think of a long journey, the strength of a "stationed" guard, and the unstoppable energy of a horse in motion.
uma.position: Standalone kanji or appears on the left side of a character.
uma.transformsMeaning: Indicates horses, speed, transportation, traveling, being stationed/stopped, or concepts associated with animals that can be ridden or used for labor.

exampleKanji.explanation: Horse (È¶¨) + master/lamp (‰∏ª). Imagine a "horse" that has stopped at a "master's" lamp‚Äîthe literal act of being "stationed" or parked.
Horse (È¶¨) + standard/ruler (Â∞∫). A "standard" place where "horses" were changed during a long journey‚Äînow the modern word for a train "station."
Horse (È¶¨) + all/whole. Originally related to a thorough "check" of a "horse's" health‚Äînow used for "testing" knowledge or having an "experience."

umareru.name: Umareru
umareru.origin: The umareru radical is a pictograph of a sprout emerging from the earth. The bottom horizontal line is the ground, and the top strokes represent the fresh leaves and stem of a plant beginning its "life." It captures the essence of growth, vitality, and the beginning of existence.
umareru.story: Life finds a way! Imagine a tiny green sprout pushing through the dark soil to reach the morning sun. This radical is the breath of all living things‚Äîrepresenting birth, production, and the vibrant "industry" of nature. When you see it, think of "newness," the act of "creating," and the simple, powerful act of being "alive."
umareru.position: Standalone kanji or appears as a central or left component of a character.
umareru.transformsMeaning: Indicates birth, life, production, raw/fresh states, students (those who are growing), and anything associated with the start or maintenance of existence.

exampleKanji.explanation: Cliff/structure + life (Áîü). To bring "life" into the world or "produce" goods within a structure‚Äîthe essence of "giving birth" and "industry."
Heart (ÂøÑ) + life (Áîü). The fundamental "nature" or "disposition" that a person is "born" with in their "heart."
Sun (Êó•) + life (Áîü). Originally suggested the "sun" giving "birth" to the many small points of light in the sky‚Äîthe countless "stars."

uo.name: Uo
uo.origin: A pictograph of a fish swimming in the water. The top („ÇØ) is the head, the middle (Áî∞) represents the scales and body, and the four dots (ÁÅ¨) at the bottom are the tail fin.
uo.story: Watch the fish dart through the clear stream! The top stroke is the pointed head, the central box shows the shimmering scales of its body, and the dots at the bottom are the fins propelling it through the water. It represents the bounty of the sea and the graceful life beneath the waves.
uo.position: Standalone kanji or on the left side (uohen)
uo.transformsMeaning: Indicates fish, seafood, aquatic life, or the act of fishing and preparing food from the sea

exampleKanji.explanation: Fish radical + sheep (Áæä) = the two foods that ancient people valued most for being served perfectly 'fresh' and vibrant.
Fish radical + capital/great (‰∫¨) = the 'great fish' of the capital of the ocean; the massive whale that reigns over the deep.
Fish radical + soil/earth (Âú≠) = the remarkable fish that returns across vast oceans to its original 'soil' (riverbed) to spawn.

ushi.name: Ushi
ushi.origin: The ushi radical is a pictograph of the head of a cow or a bull, viewed from the front. The top vertical stroke is a horn, the horizontal strokes are the face and ears, and the central vertical line is the snout. It captures the essential form of a sturdy bovine.
ushi.story: Strong as an ox! Imagine a powerful bull standing in a field, a symbol of patience and provider of life. This radical represents the livestock that have supported agriculture for millenia. When you see it, think of physical "strength," the "goods" we produce, and the steady, reliable "vessel" that a cow represents in human history.
ushi.position: Standalone kanji or can appear at the top or bottom of a character.
ushi.transformsMeaning: Indicates cows, bulls, cattle, livestock, physical strength, animal-based products (milk/meat), or concepts of patience and sacrifice.

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for cattle, the heart of traditional farming and a primary source of nourishment and strength.
Cow (Áâõ) + mouth (Âè£). Originally related to a "cow" being used in a ritual where "words" were spoken‚Äînow the standard kanji for "announcing" or telling.
Cow/livestock (Áâõ variant) + color/variety. Originally suggested a "variety" of "cattle" or livestock‚Äînow the general word for any "thing" or object.

ushihen.name: Ushihen
ushihen.origin: The ushihen radical is the narrowed "left side" form of the cow radical (Áâõ). The bottom horizontal stroke is slanted upward (slanted cow) to fit beside the other components, but it retains its original meaning as a symbol of sturdy livestock and physical material.
ushihen.story: The provider on the left! When the "cow" moves to the side, it sets the stage for characters related to physical "things" and the "sacrifice" required for sacred rites. Imagine a cow being led to a market or a shrine. It represents the "material" world‚Äîthe objects we touch, the animals we raise, and the "special" status of something chosen for a purpose.
ushihen.position: Always appears on the LEFT side of the kanji.
ushihen.transformsMeaning: Indicates physical objects (things), specific types of animals, sacrifice, special status, or the concept of materials and livestock.

exampleKanji.explanation: Cow (Áâõ) + temple (ÂØ∫). Represents a "cow" that has been chosen for a "temple" ritual‚Äîsomething that is "special" and set apart from the rest.
Cow (Áâõ) + hand/tool (Êîµ). To use a tool to guide a "cow" in a field‚Äîthe essence of a "pasture" or "breeding" animals.
Cow (Áâõ) + moral/righteous. A "cow" offered in a "righteous" ritual‚Äîthe literal image of a "sacrifice" made for a greater purpose.

usu.name: Usu
usu.origin: The usu radical is a pictograph of a mortar (a bowl used for grinding). The outer frame is the bowl, and the horizontal strokes on the sides represent the teeth or the grain being crushed within. It captures the essential tool used for grinding grain and preparing food.
usu.story: Grind it down! Imagine a sturdy stone mortar sitting in a kitchen, ready to turn raw grain into flour. This radical represents "interest," "amusement," and the hard work of transformation. When you see it, think of the rhythmic motion of grinding and the "excitement" of creating something new through persistent effort and focus.
usu.position: Standalone kanji or appears at the top or center of a character.
usu.transformsMeaning: Indicates mortars, grinding tools, preparation of food, intense focus/excitement (as in grinding away at a task), or the concept of a hollow container.

exampleKanji.explanation: Mortar (Ëáº) + four hands + mouth/bottom. Imagine many "hands" working together at a "mortar" to build something great‚Äîthe essence of "prospering" and "active interest."
Water (Ê∞µ) + mortar (Ëáº) + sun/bird. Originally referred to a "hollow" place where "water" gathers (like a mortar)‚Äîthe standard kanji for a "lagoon."
Mortar-like head (Ëáº variant) + body + tail. A pictograph of a rodent, where the "mortar" shape represents its busy, gnawing head.

wakanmuri.name: Wakanmuri
wakanmuri.origin: The wakanmuri radical is a pictograph of a cloth cover or a lid placed over an object to conceal or protect it. It is simpler than the "roof" radical (ÂÆÄ), as it lacks the top chimney dot, representing a flat "crown" or covering used to copy or settle things.
wakanmuri.story: Place a cover on it! Imagine a thin, elegant cloth being draped over a precious object to keep it safe from dust or prying eyes. This radical represents the act of "covering" or "settling" a character. When you see it at the top, think of the "crown" of a copy, the "lid" on a deep bottle, or the way we "settle" into a final state.
wakanmuri.position: Always appears at the TOP of the kanji.
wakanmuri.transformsMeaning: Indicates covers, lids, crowns, concealing, wrapping, or concepts related to copying (placing a sheet over another) and settling/finishing.

exampleKanji.explanation: Cover/crown (ÂÜñ) + a bird variant. Originally related to the way a bird "settles" under a cover, now the standard kanji for "copying" or taking a photograph.
Cover (ÂÜñ) + source + inch/law. A formal "covering" for the head that follows traditional "law"‚Äîthe literal image of a "crown."
Cover (ÂÜñ) + rabbit. Imagine a rabbit being trapped under a "cover"‚Äîthe original image of being "falsely charged" or suffering an "injustice."

ya.name: Ya
ya.origin: The ya radical is a literal pictograph of an arrow. The top part is the pointed arrowhead, the horizontal stroke represents the fletching (feathers), and the central vertical line is the shaft. It captures the essence of a weapon that travels in a straight, direct line.
ya.story: Straight as an arrow! Imagine a wooden arrow notched into a bow, ready to fly toward its target. This radical represents "directness," "speed," and the "decisive" nature of finding an answer. When you see it, think of the power of a single, sharp retort and the focused knowledge that "knows" exactly where to strike.
ya.position: Standalone kanji or appears on the left side of a character.
ya.transformsMeaning: Indicates arrows, distance (bow-shot), speed, directness, decisiveness, or concepts related to knowing (direct knowledge) and health (shot with an arrow).

exampleKanji.explanation: The base kanji for an arrow, a symbol of directness and traditional weaponry used in battle and hunting.
Arrow (Áü¢) + mouth (Âè£). To have knowledge that is as "direct" and "decisive" as an "arrow" leaving the moth‚Äîthe literal act of "knowing."
Arrow (Áü¢) + bean/vessel (Ë±Ü). Originally suggested a "short" distance, like the length of an "arrow" compared to a long "vessel"‚Äîthe opposite of long.

yahen.name: Yahen
yahen.origin: The yahen radical is the narrowed "left side" form of the arrow radical (Áü¢). It retains its original pictographic shape of an arrowhead, shaft, and fletching, representing the same energy of directness and speed used to define the action of the kanji.
yahen.story: Directness on the left! When the "arrow" moves to the side, it sets the stage for characters related to "knowing," "notifying," and the physical "shortness" of an object. Imagine an arrow pointing the way toward a hidden truth. It represents the sharp, focused energy needed to "notify" others or reach a clear "consent."
yahen.position: Always appears on the LEFT side of the kanji.
yahen.transformsMeaning: Indicates directness, focused knowledge, speed, shortness, notification, or the act of providing a formal consent or answer.

exampleKanji.explanation: Arrow (Áü¢) + mouth (Âè£). To speak "words" that are as "direct" as an "arrow"‚Äîthe fundamental act of "knowing" a fact.
Arrow (Áü¢) + bean/vessel (Ë±Ü). A "short" distance, originally comparing the length of an "arrow" to a standard measuring vessel.
Arrow (Áü¢) + tall/high. To "rectify" or "correct" an "arrow" that is not "straight" or tall‚Äîthe act of fixing a mistake.

yama.name: Yama
yama.origin: A clear pictograph of three mountain peaks rising against the sky. The central peak is the highest, flanked by two supporting ridges on either side.
yama.story: Stand tall and look at the horizon! Three peaks reach for the clouds in perfect harmony. This character is the bedrock of geography, representing strength, height, and the enduring nature of the earth that outlasts human life.
yama.position: Standalone, on the left (yamahen), or at the top (yamakanmuri)
yama.transformsMeaning: Indicates mountains, rocks, height, or wild, natural places far from the city

exampleKanji.explanation: Mountain + stone (Áü≥) = the large, heavy stones that make up the body of a mountain.
Mountain + bird (È≥• simplified) = a mountain rising out of the sea where weary birds go to rest.
Mountain + cliff + dry = the high, dry land where the mountains meet the water's edge.

yamaidare.name: Yamaidare
yamaidare.origin: The yamaidare radical is a pictograph representing a person lying on a frame or a primitive bed (represented by the top and left strokes) because they are ill. It captures the essence of weakness and the physical state of requiring medical care.
yamaidare.story: Rest and recover! Imagine a person tucked under a blanket, lying in a quiet room while they wait for their fever to break. This radical is the spirit of healing and the struggle against "sickness." When you see it hanging from the top-left, think of the "treatment" needed to get well, the "pain" of a long illness, and the "fatigue" we feel when our bodies are taxed.
yamaidare.position: Always appears at the TOP and LEFT of the kanji.
yamaidare.transformsMeaning: Indicates sickness, diseases, medicine, hospitals, medical treatment, physical weakness, fatigue, or the concept of a long-term ailment.

exampleKanji.explanation: Sickness (Áñí) + light/fire variant. The process of using "fire" or "light" (energy) to "treat" a "sickness"‚Äîthe essence of medical care.
Sickness (Áñí) + passing through. The feeling of a "sickness" or injury "passing through" your body‚Äîthe literal experience of "pain."
Sickness (Áñí) + skin/pelt. Imagine your "skin" feeling heavy like it's a "sickness"‚Äîthe deep "fatigue" that follows hard work or illness.

yamakanmuri.name: Yamakanmuri
yamakanmuri.origin: The yamakanmuri radical is the "crown" form of the mountain radical (Â±±). It represents the same three peaks rising from the earth, but it is positioned at the top of a character to show that the concept below is related to the height, the coast, or the majesty of the peaks.
yamakanmuri.story: The peak at the top! Imagine the jagged summit of a great mountain overlooking the shore. This radical brings the energy of physical "height" and the "obstacles" of the landscape to a kanji. When you see it at the top, think of the "rocky" edge of a coast, the "islands" rising from the sea, and the "majestic" presence of a mountain guarding the land.
yamakanmuri.position: Always appears at the TOP of the kanji.
yamakanmuri.transformsMeaning: Indicates mountains, height, coasts (where mountains meet the sea), cliffs, rocky terrain, islands, or concepts of majesty and rugged beauty.

exampleKanji.explanation: Mountain (Â±±) + cliff + dry/shield. The "shore" or "coast" where the "mountains" and "cliffs" meet the water‚Äîa rugged and "dry" boundary.
Mountain (Â±±) + bird + mountain variant. Originally showed a "bird" resting on a "mountain" rising out of the sea‚Äîthe literal image of an "island."
Mountain (Â±±) + stone (Áü≥). The "stones" found high up on a "mountain"‚Äîthe standard kanji for a large "rock" or boulder.

yokome.name: Yokome
yokome.origin: The yokome radical is a flattened, "horizontal" (yoko) form of the eye radical (ÁõÆ). It represents the same pictograph of a human eye with its pupil and lids, but it was reshaped to sit on top of other components, often representing a watchful eye or a "net" used to capture truth or criminals.
yokome.story: Watch from above! Imagine an eye turned on its side to peer down from the roof of a building. This radical is the spirit of "supervision," "judgment," and the "net" that captures those who break the law. When you see it at the top, think of an official "station," the "sin" that is observed, and the "punishment" delivered by a watchful authority.
yokome.position: Always appears at the TOP of the kanji.
yokome.transformsMeaning: Indicates eyes, watching/supervision, judgment, legal networks (nets), official stations, sins, or the concept of an observing presence from above.

exampleKanji.explanation: Eye crown (ÁΩí) + person + sun/field. A "station" where "people" work under a "watchful eye" to serve the public‚Äîlike a police or fire station.
Eye/net (ÁΩí) + wrong/not. Imagine someone being caught in a "net" for doing something "wrong"‚Äîthe literal image of a "sin" or crime.
Eye/net (ÁΩí) + shell/money (Ë≤ù). Originally suggested "shells" (money) being "watched" or gathered in a "net"‚Äîthe act of purchasing or "buying."

yumi.name: Yumi
yumi.origin: A pictograph of a recurve bow used for archery. The shape shows the bow bent and held under tension, ready to release its power through an arrow.
yumi.story: See the curve of a great bow held steady by a master archer! This character represents the beauty of tension and the potential of energy waiting to be released. It is the root of kanji related to archery, stretching, and anything that bends without breaking.
yumi.position: Standalone kanji or on the left side (yumihen)
yumi.transformsMeaning: Indicates bows, archery, the act of bending or stretching, or the state of being under tension

exampleKanji.explanation: Bow radical + a single line = the act of drawing back the string of a bow before releasing the arrow.
Bow radical + personal/self = the vast, wide arc of a powerful bow stretching out toward the horizon.
Bow radical + insect/creature (mushi) = the tremendous physical strength required to string and draw a bow made of animal horn and sinew.

yuube.name: Yuube
yuube.origin: The yuube radical is a pictograph of a crescent moon rising in the sky, specifically representing the time when the sun has set but the moon is not yet high‚Äîthe "evening." It is distinguished from the "moon" (Êúà) by having only one internal horizontal stroke.
yuube.story: As the sun sets... Imagine the soft, orange glow of twilight as the first sliver of the moon appears. This radical is the spirit of transition, the beauty of the "night," and the many "names" and dreams we speak in the quiet of the dusk. When you see it, think of "tonight," the deep "darkness" of midnight, and the peaceful end of another day.
yuube.position: Standalone kanji or appears on the left or top of a character.
yuube.transformsMeaning: Indicates evening, night, twilight, time periods after sunset, dreams, names (originally whispered at night), and concepts related to darkness and transition.

exampleKanji.explanation: Evening (Â§ï) + person + cover variant. The time when a "person" is under the "cover" of the "evening" sky‚Äîthe standard word for the "night."
Evening (Â§ï) + mouth (Âè£). Originally, since people couldn't see each other in the "darkness" of "evening," they had to use their "mouths" to call out their "names."
Evening (Â§ï) + divining/stick (Âçú). Originally suggested "divining" the future by looking at the "evening" sky from "outside" the house.
